dialogues.text: Ms. Lerner, Tom Beck. I understand you've come into a little information. Jenny stands there as if slapped. Beck offers the smile that got him elected. Holy shit, the water's suddenly very deep.

dialogues.speaker: ENTREKIN
dialogues.text: Ms. Lerner was just expressing her lack of enthusiasm for matters of national security when journalist competitiveness is at stake. Beck nods, seeming to agree with Jenny. The reasonable, understanding father, the legislative compromiser. Jenny' staring at him. He's not unaware of the effect he's havin on her. She takes a deep breath, plays her only card.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (fighting now to collapse in front of the man) At this moment Mr. President, I am not interested in using Ellie to further my career. When she says the word Ellie, the President studies her. He wants to speak to her as someone he can trust.

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: So what do you know about E.L.E.? When Jenny hears the phrase E.L.E. something snaps into place. She realizes she has a card to play for the first time since she was taken here.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I know you should have chosen a better cover story than a sick wife. Beck looks unhappily to Entrekin. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: You see? What did I say? Entrekin holds up his hands, guilty as charged.

dialogues.speaker: BECK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We always thought that the deadline for going public was the publication of the budget. We've spent more money than we could hide. But the budget comes out in two weeks. I don't suppose I can convince you to sit on this for two weeks?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: There's no such thing as two weeks in the news business.

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: And I can't appeal to your sense of what's in the nation's best interest.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I always thought the truth was in the nation's best interest. Beck and Entrekin look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: ENTREKIN
dialogues.text: Should we hold her?

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: What if we went public in forty- eight hours? That's doable, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: ENTREKIN
dialogues.text: It'd be very difficult.

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: If she knows, how many days before The Post or CNN break the story? This was never going to be a secret as long as you wanted it to be, Morton. (back to Jenny) If you give us two days, you get second row center at the White House press conference. And from what I know about your career, that's a promotion. She considers this. She has to play a big card.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I want exclusivity. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: Now you listen to me, Ms. Lerner. This is a Presidential favor. I'm letting you go because I don't want another headache and I'm trusting you because I know what this can do for your career. Somehow, we have each other over the same barrel. But who really has the power in this room? He's scary, and they're eye to eye. But she is still stro enough for one last volley.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I want the first question.

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: Want?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: May I? May I have the first question?

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: (the political pro) See you on Tuesday, Ms. Lerner.

dialogues.speaker: MSNBC.NEWSROOM
dialogues.text: Jenny rushes into the newsroom, most of the desks are emp save for a small news staff, the anchor out front, and a cleaning crew. She tosses her stuff down, throws herself front of her computer, types in ELE. BEEP...BEEP! The screen comes alive with hits. Paint companies, an exterminating outfit in Atlanta, an upholsterer in Boise, a website for Ella Fitzgerald. She jumps to information on Ellesmere Island and it's sno blasted Eskimo settlements. Nothing's right. She then has a thought and types in E.L.E. The search reveals a single hit: E.L.E. -- see University of Califor at Berkeley, Department of Paleontology.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: What does Paleontology have to do with anything? Next hit -- Department of Paleontology. A list of sub- headings: Invertebrate Paleontology, Vertebrate Paleontology, Oceanographic Prehistory, Hominid Paleontol (see Department of Anthropology), Extinction Studies. Tha stops her. She clicks on "Extinction Studies". Up comes a graphic with the dinosaurs and the comet, and the definition: E.L.E. -- Extinction Level Event. She clicks the hot word, "Extinction" and up comes: "The or fact of dying; death, decease, demise, dissolution, passing, quietus, rest." We're close on Jenny when we hea

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Hey, look who's working late. Jenny is petrified, but covers.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Hi. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: How're we doing on Rittenhouse? It's Beth, carrying her daughter, Caitlin, briefcase slun over one shoulder. She's on her way home.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I... Uh... No sign of his wife, not yet, we're working on it. We'll get her.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Is she missing?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY'
dialogues.text: She's not available for comment.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I know it's a dull story ...

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Yeah

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I'll find something more exciting for you next time.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Come to dinner with us?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I have to meet my Father.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Then I'll see you tomorrow. Say goodnight, Caitlin...

dialogues.speaker: CAITLIN
dialogues.text: .. night... What Beth hasn't seen is Jenny's computer screen: a full color and text encyclopedia page, illustrated dinosaurs, comet, extinction.  40

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A great old wood paneled bar. JASON LERNER is about sixty three; an international lawyer, serious and somewhat guarded. His relationship with his daughter is civil, and terrible. CHLOE WEBBER, his new wife, is just two years older than Jenny. She is not a joke, which makes this mor painful. Of course she is lovely, but she is a serious person, too, not unlike his daughter.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Here she is. Jenny... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: 40A CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And Jenny comes into the room, looking like she just foun out the world is coming to an end. The more deeply she stares into herself, the more her father and mother-in-la read this as hatred of them. The Waiter arrives.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Would you like a drink?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: A big Martini, up, big.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I missed you yesterday. It hurt me very much that you didn't come to the wedding.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: (making peach) Jason, you promised. Jenny I wanted you to have something. She hands her a blue box from Tiffany. Jenny stares at th box, as though she's never seen a present. She gives him no reaction. Indicates another round for hi and Chloe. The waiter leaves. Jenny handles the box without comprehension.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Jenny, you should open the present. Jenny opens it numbly. Two pearl earrings. She shakes her head, but not about this.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: You can always exchange them if you don't like them. I know this is hard, but I want you to be happy.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Happy. The drinks arrive. Jason lifts his glass. While Jason is talking, Jenny downs the Martini.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Alright. I want to forget about yesterday, and I want to say how important it is to me that we're together now. But Jenny had finished her Martini in the first five word of the toast, and she's staring deep into herself.

dialogues.speaker: JASON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are we going to have an evening or not? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: I know you hate me. I know you want to say something terrible to me. I know you want to ask me what my major is, or how long I've been driving, or if my mother let's me cross the street by myself. But my parents were divorced too. You have to get over it. Life goes on. Jenny looks at her, and starts to smile, and then laughs herself.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Life goes on. (a beat) Dad, you have to get back with Mom. She's all alone in the world, and she needs you.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Jenny, I got married yesterday. (to Chloe) I'm sorry for the way my daughter is behaving.

dialogues.speaker: CHLOE
dialogues.text: (she's not happy) It's not your fault.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I have to go. I'm not a bad person. I'm really not. I know you think I am and I don't hate you. I have to go. Jenny gets up and leaves. We stay with Jason and Chloe. She picks up the earrings. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The press corps is in full force. Reporters every ten feet, each with a backdrop of the White House. We TRACK ALONG, hearing them all say essentially the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: BRENT HUME
dialogues.text: President Beck begins his address in fifteen minutes...

dialogues.speaker: COKEY ROBERTS
dialogues.text: The White House has maintained a complete blackout on the purpose of tonight's speech...

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH REPORTER
dialogues.text: Le President a demande ace que les televisions du monde entier...

dialogues.speaker: AFRICAN REPORTER
dialogues.text: Hotuba itatafsiriwa kwa lugha mia moja na ishirnini...

dialogues.speaker: WHITE HOUSE PRESS ROOM
dialogues.text: Jenny shoves her way through the tangle of reporters and cameras, makes her way slowly. Uncertain where to go.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Jenny...? Beth coming through the crowd. Shocked to see Jenny.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? Beth stares down at Jenny's White House credentials. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stuart sent you without telling me?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (trapped) No, I a... I was going to talk to you about this but...

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (she's pissed) If Stuart thinks he can push me out of the White House after all these years --

dialogues.speaker: ENTREKIN
dialogues.text: Ms. Lerner? Morton Entrekin interrupts, takes Jenny's arm.

dialogues.speaker: ENTREKIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hi, Beth... Pulls her to the front of the room. Beth is left behind, stunned. Watching them go. Jenny steals a look back.

dialogues.speaker: ENTREKIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He'll find you for the first question, after that, you're on your own. Entrekin rips a "Reserved" sign off a chair dead center. Plops the dazed Jenny into it and is gone. All around her, seasoned reporters stare; Hume, Roberts, Thomas, Lowenstall. But nobody's staring harder than Beth, taking her seat three rows back on the side.

dialogues.speaker: STOFSKY
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen...please! It's the Press Secretary, standing at the lectern in fron of the White House seal, trying to get their attention.

dialogues.speaker: STOFSKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The President will begin by addressing the nation. Please hold your questions until he's finished his remarks. The room quiets as cameras swing to find President Beck and his entourage entering.

dialogues.speaker: STOFSKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, the President of the United States. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Still cameras WHIR, electronic flashes POP. Beck takes the stage, smiles warmly to the assembled.

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: Hello everybody.

dialogues.speaker: ASST DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Ten seconds Mr. President... Beck finds Jenny. Nods. Straightens himself up.

dialogues.speaker: ASST DIRECTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Five...four... Counts down the last three on his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: Good evening. A few minutes ago, the United States Ambassadors to every country in the world told the leaders of those nations what I am about to tell you. It's complicated and it's going to take a little time, so I hope you'll bear with me and listen to what I have to say. A little over eight months ago two American astronomers, Marcus Wolf and Leo Biederman, working alone ona mountaintop in Arizona, saw something in the night sky that gave them great concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Biederman family is watching.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Nobody say anything.

dialogues.speaker: BECK, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: They saw a comet, and the comet was, well, there was a remote possibility that the comet was on a path that could bring it into direct contact with the Earth.

dialogues.speaker: MSNBC NEWSROOM
dialogues.text: The President's on every monitor, but the newsroom EXPLOD People leap for phones and computers, it's bedlam.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: We need astronomers, astrophysicists, geologists, climatologists! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The CAMEP 33A-33B. 47

dialogues.speaker: IRA MOSKATEL
dialogues.text: Where the hell is Science!?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Paris, London, Tokyo, Tel Aviv... everywhere, hell yes! A roams through the chaos.

dialogues.speaker: WORTH
dialogues.text: Who was that guy at Berkeley, did the Hale-Bopp stand-ups?

dialogues.speaker: IRA MOSKATEL
dialogues.text: And graphics, I need graphics! (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: WHITE HOUSE PRESS ROOM
dialogues.text: The President continues, teleprompter feeding him his wor

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: Now, we get hit every day by rocks and meteors, some of them are the size of cars and some of them the size of your hand. But the comet we discovered is the size of New York City from Central Park to the tip of the Island, about seven miles long. Put another way, the comet is larger than Mount Everest, and weighs five hundred billion tons. The room stirs, reporters stare at each other. Jenny's rapt, she knew the punch line, but not the joke.

dialogues.speaker: BECK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Chances are, this thing will miss us, because comets aren't on railroad tracks, they're sliding and side-slipping through space. But this one is too big for us to just cross our fingers and hope it scoots on by. So tonight, I want to tell you what I can about what we're doing to take care of the comet before there's even a chance it might hit us. And if the grown- ups of the world don't mind, right now I want to talk to the children of the world.

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBORHOOD CHICAGO BAR
dialogues.text: Everyone watches as the speech continues. The BARTENDER reaches for a bottle of the oldest scotch on the shelf an starts to pour tall drinks without comment. A SMOKER reaches into his pocket and takes out a full pack of cigarettes. He blithely holds it open and EVERYONE at the bar reaches for one.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE HOUSE PRESS ROOM
dialogues.text: The President walks to a large monitor on stage with him. Projected on the TV, we see a NASA film about the comet.

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: Comets begin far out in space. They're what's left over from the creation of the solar system after the planets were formed, billions of years ago. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BECK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These chunks of space debris are in an orbit around the sun, very much like our own, but every now and then; one of them is bumped, a bit like a billiard ball (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BECK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: on a pool table, and it gets knocked into a new orbit.

dialogues.speaker: MSNBC NEWSROOM
dialogues.text: People are screaming on the phones. A few are in shock, still watching the set, Bobby's one of them.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: We've got stand-ups on line; Beijing, Rome, San Paulo, Cairo, Berlin... (yelling out) Anybody know how big the one was that wiped out the dinosaurs! A musician sets up a portable keyboard to begin composing Worth frantically gives him instructions.

dialogues.speaker: WORTH
dialogues.text: Something majestic, mysterious, with a fanfare for intros and a theme for longer promos The CAMERA finds Stuart and Ira hunched over a computer monitor with a graphic artist working on a comet graphic.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: It's hitting the goddamn earth!

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: That's what he's saying!

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: It'll scare the shit outta everybody!

dialogues.speaker: NEW YORK CITY
dialogues.text: The streets are alive with people, people pouring outside some with binoculars and long lenses on their cameras, everyone looking up, to see the comet.

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: Now, if the comet passes around the sun and were to hold to it's present course, then sometime on August 16, 2000 there's a chance we might have an impact. Jenny's sitting there with her notebook, what's she going to say when the time comes? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BECK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So for the past eight months, the United States and Russia have been building the largest spaceship ever constructed; it's being built in orbit around the earth. We call it the Messiah. I want to emphasize that some scientists argued that there was no reason to spend the time and money to intercept something that probably won't hit us, but we decided not to take that risk. And right now, a team of American astronauts, and one Russian, are at Cape Canaveral in Florida. In two months they will leave on the Shuttle to board the Messiah; this is the crew that will stop the comet.

dialogues.speaker: CANAVERAL SHUTTLE PREP BUILDING
dialogues.text: Five men and one woman in new flight suits.

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: I'd like the world to meet some extraordinary people. First is Mission Commander Oren Monash. Commander, would you introduce us to your Team?

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: It'd be an honor, sir. Executive Officer Andrea Baker, Navigator Mark Simon, Medical Officer Gus Partenza, from Russia, Nuclear Specialist Colonel Mikhail Tulchinsky, and Rendezvous Pilot Spurgeon Tanner. BAKER has the relaxed confidence of a woman who has never failed at anything. SIMON is black, military. TULCHINSKY, being Russian, shows his life on his face, every woman, every smile, every heart-break.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUTS
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: Captain Tanner, you flew six Shuttle Missions and were the last man to walk on the moon, weren't you sir? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. But Oren will be doing most of the flying on this one. I'll just be taking us down to the comet surface. Monash is smiling for the camera, but something's going o behind his eyes. Jealousy? Pride? Frustration? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: It's good to know we're going to have your kind of experience up there. Godspeed to you all. We're counting on you. The cameras' red lights go dark at the Cape. The astronau drop their public personas, pull off their mikes.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: Goddamn dog and pony show. Monash shoots a look to Tanner, starts off.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Are we having a problem, son?

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: ...No problem... But he doesn't look back. Tanner watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE HOUSE PRESS ROOM
dialogues.text: Beck's back at his podium.

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: I want to let the children know that you're going to hear a lot of people worrying about this. Some of your Moms and Dads, grandparents, even your big brothers and sisters... well, they might be scared. So I'm telling you to tell them, everything is going to be okay. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: UNIVERSAL CITY WALK
dialogues.text: The big TV screen, the President. People pour out of the Cineplex to watch as the word spreads.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE HOUSE PRESS ROOM
dialogues.text: Beck drops the smile he'd used for the kids, looks direct into CAMERA, suddenly hard, tough.

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: Now I want to talk to the grownups. We know that the threat of an apocalypse is going to give some people an excuse for lawlessness. As of this evening, I've placed the National Guard and the Army on full alert. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BECK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We will not tolerate any disruption of our way of life. Our society will continue as normal. Work will go on. You will pay your bills. As the CAMERA moves in slowly on Beck, Jenny shifts in he seat, preparing for the biggest moment of her life.

dialogues.speaker: BECK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There will be no hoarding. There will be no sudden profiteering. I am freezing all wages, all prices. I have instructed the Secretary of the Treasury to close the nation's financial markets. All stock bond, interest and commodity rates, all currency exchange rates and precious metal prices will remain fixed at today's prices. What a bottle of water cost you yesterday, it will cost you tomorrow. Anyone selling something for more than it cost this morning will be arrested. Anyone rioting, anyone looting, anyone.., well, that person is going to be shot on sight. (let's it sink in) Now I'll take a few questions. All hands shoot up in the air, questions are shouted. The sound of Nikon MOTORS and SHUTTERS is like jungle noise i a Tarzan movie. Jenny tries to be heard, but she's a novice, buried by the regulars.

dialogues.speaker: BECK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ms. Lerner? who? The press room regulars look around. Jenny. It's her moment in the sun, she stands.. Man, is she nervous.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Jenny Lerner, MSNBC. Mr. President, why wasn't the announcement made sooner?

dialogues.speaker: MSNBC NEWSROOM
dialogues.text: Chaos reigns, anchors move into place, ready themselves for when the press conference ends. But Stuart's head has snapped around to stare at the screen, his mouth open.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANNE
dialogues.text: Jenny Lerner?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: But Eric and Bobby are grinning in back, loving it.

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: Until we knew that a rocket could be built and the comet intercepted, there was no reason to alarm the planet. Beth's staring at the back of Jenny's head, if she had an ice pick she'd bury it in her scrawny skull. Everyone raises their hands for the next question, yelling.

dialogues.speaker: BECK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have another question, Ms. Lerner? She didn't really. She fumbles nervously. The press corp' near mutiny, the fix is in and they know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin and her STAFF, putting their magazine together, watching Jenny on TV as she asks a question. Some look from Robin to the set and back, as she is comprehending that her daughter has just moved up in the world.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Is there a connection between the comet and the recall of American troops from abroad? Beck's not happy with that question.

dialogues.speaker: BECK, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Our fighting men and women are coming home because we felt it prudent in light of domestic security concerns, to have them available, although I certainly hope we don't need to use them. (looks for next question) Joy and Robin share a smile, her mother's daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason and Chloe watch Jenny on TV.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Mr. President! Sir! One final question! Now they understand why she was behaving so strangely at the bar.  61

dialogues.speaker: WHITE HOUSE PRESS ROOM
dialogues.text: Beck smiles, points to her again. Now it's not only Beth, the entire Press Corp's sharpening their long knives.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: MSNBC has learned that Secretary Rittenhouse did not leave for the reasons your administration announced. Isn't it true sir, that not everyone in your administration is convinced that the Messiah will save us? Beck gives Jenny a hard look.

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: Secretary Rittenhouse served this country with full devotion, and resigned for personal reasons. We have more important things before us than to consider the petty soap opera of Washington. I promise you, Ms. Lerner, and all of you, those in this room and those hearing my voice, that all of us, at some point in the next eight months, will entertain our worst fears and concerns. But I promise you, life will go on. We shall prevail. There will be no Armageddon! The questions erupt again. Beck nods to Jenny, she smiles sits. This part of their deal concluded.

dialogues.speaker: BECK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pointing) David.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Exactly when and how was the comet discovered?

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: Two scientists searching the skies found the comet and while racing from their observatory to alert the world, were killed in a car crash. That was thirteen months ago. It took another five months for their papers to be discovered. The questions erupt again. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BECK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sally?

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER REPORTER
dialogues.text: Sir, what's the comet's name?

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: Since Marcus Wolf and his colleague Leo Biederman discovered the comet we named it for them: Wolf- Biederman.

dialogues.speaker: BIEDERMAN HOUSE
dialogues.text: Leo and his family watch in their suburban living room. His father, DON. Mother, ELLEN. Little sister, JANE.

dialogues.speaker: DON BIEDERMAN
dialogues.text: Leo Biederman? They watch in shock. Their phone begins to RING.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: He means you doesn't he?

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: How much notice did you give other world leaders? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Shhh... I'm trying to listen!

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: Our ambassadors were given briefing papers this afternoon, and instructed to convey them to their host countries. The Russians, with their expertise in nuclear propulsion systems, were told last year. Now the DOORBELL joins the phone that's still RINGING. Jane looks at all the grown-ups not answering either, confused. Hops off the couch, heads for the front door. On the TV, President Beck concludes the questioning.

dialogues.speaker: BECK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you all. Beck steps back from the podium, heads for the door as reporters continue to SHOUT questions. Six year old Jane stands beside Leo.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: The front door's for you. Leo turns away from the set, walks to the still open fron door, still in shock. It's Sarah, breathless. Excited.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: I'm not dead.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Dr. Wolf? From astronomy club?

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: I think maybe so. Leo looks past her to the residential street and a crowd outside. The Hotchners are on the lawn behind Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I think it's neat. Nobody on our block ever discovered the world was going to end before.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: It's not going to end.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Well it's still really neat.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE HOUSE PRESS ROOM
dialogues.text: It's clearing out, fast. TV rushing to stand-ups. Print phoning copy desks. Jenny stands, still at her place in the second row of the now almost empty room. Savoring it, this moment, everything she's worked for. Turns. Beth's there. Doesn't say anything. Turns, and walks away. Leaving Jenny alone. Jenny wants to feel ashamed, or guilty. But she doesn't. She's where she's always wanted to be.

dialogues.speaker: LEO'S SCHOOL AUDITORIUM
dialogues.text: Everyone is cheering and clapping for Leo on stage. Mr. Perry's there moderating. Leo's parents. The local press is in full force. Sarah's with her girlfriends.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: It was really just luck, I guess, that I found it. Anyone could have. As far as we know, what happened was that Dr. Wolf saw the comet in my photograph so he shared the discovery with me. Then he was killed in that crash and everything got mixed up in Washington so the President thought I was dead too.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: How does it make you feel having your name on it? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Well, I don't want anyone to think that I'm trying to take something away from Dr. Wolf, because, you know... I'm not. One of Sarah's friends nudges her, shows her a Newsweek: Leo on the cover with his telescope.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: Are you sorry you found it?

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: No. If I hadn't taken that picture of the comet, and it hadn't gone to Dr. Wolf at the observatory, who knows what would have happened? Sarah leans forward, calls out a question.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Are you scared?

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: I have a history test tomorrow. I'm scared of that. Appreciative laughter and applause from the student audie and the press. Another kid, a smartass showing off.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You know you're going to have sex a lot more now than anyone else in our class. That gets a chorus of adolescent HOOTS and APPLAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Really? Perry intercedes good-naturedly.

dialogues.speaker: PERRY
dialogues.text: Thanks for your sexual insight Mr. Thurman, you can sit down now. But all the attention only spurs the kid on.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Famous people always get sex, Mr. Perry. That's one of the main reasons it's good to be famous. More applause, Perry smiles, Harold takes a bow to his adoring peers. Leo sneaks a look out to Sarah. She's smiling back. All this talk about sex. Her friends notice, grin. Sarah notices them noticing.  68

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simon, Tulchinsky, Monash, Baker, and Partenza are sittin at a table in a crowded military bar. The juke box is playing. The Astronauts are deep in a somewhat drunken huddle. Monash is upset.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: Frank Gifford was a great football player, but I'd bust his ass if he played against me now.

dialogues.speaker: PARTENZA
dialogues.text: I wish I'd been to the moon, I respect everyone who went there, but this isn't the moon.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: All of his training was for a stable surface, the moon didn't have two pound dust particles ejecting at three hundred feet a second.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: This isn't about ego.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Of course it is, it's all about ego... but sometimes the ego is right. '

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: And dust particles...

dialogues.speaker: PARTENZA
dialogues.text: (drunker than the others) The moon, the moon, the moon wasn't spinning when he landed on it, the moon didn't have a fourteen hour rotay... Rotational period, seven hours of sun, seven hours of darkness, it was light all the time when he landed on the moon. He could see. We're not going to be able to see.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: You can't see now anyway.

dialogues.speaker: TULCHINSKY
dialogues.text: Don't worry... (in Russian) We can do it.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: What?  44A.

dialogues.speaker: TULCHINSKY
dialogues.text: We can do it. And then we hear a familiar Voice.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: I woke up this morning and I realized that none of you want me here. You don't even really know who I am. I walked on the moon, but I didn't belong to you. I belonged to your Daddies. Now, if I ask you to ask your Daddies what I meant to them, to explain to you what I'm doing here, that's only going to make things worse. So what do we do?  44B-46.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: You haven't trained for this mission. We respect you...

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: I appreciate that...

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: But you're here...you're here because the powers that be think we need someone familiar on the trip. You're here for public relations.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: I'm here because the powers that be know that I am the only one on this mission who has ever landed on the moon and I have five hundred landings on aircraft carriers...

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: We've trained...

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: On flight simulators. And this is not a video game, son.

dialogues.text: Leo's little sister JANE changes the channel on the TV. O every station there's a comet graphic, some in the manner Chuck Jones, others are Soviet Realism, Moebius, computer enhanced photos of the real thing. This is all that anyon is watching or talking about. She lands on a documentary.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: I want Xena! Where's Xena? The phone's RINGING. Ellen answers it.  69 47.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Jane, please, it's not The Tunguska River, Siberia, on anymore, in 1908, trees fell for 30 (into phone) miles... A railroad engineer No... dialogues.text: Primetime Live again. Jane changes channels to find POLITICALLY INCORRECT.

dialogues.text: Is the sky really falling? Do we really think the world is coming to an end? And how can we trust Russian nuclear rockets when the Russians can't figure out how to get phones to work in Moscow?

dialogues.text: I love the comet! I want to die! I want everyone to die! You know how you hate it when you leave the room and you know everyone is going to talk about you? That's one problem that the comet's going to take care of!

dialogues.speaker: BILL MAHER
dialogues.text: I think they only say lovely things about me. GOLDTHWAITE. Leave the room. Changes channels again. LETTERMAN.

dialogues.speaker: LEO AND SARAH'S STREET
dialogues.text: Sarah comes out of her house. The street is deserted, TVs dance in every living room window. A SOUND. Wheels on pavement. Leo rollerblades across the street under the streetlight.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Hi... Leo stops, smiles. Watches her approach.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: You're not watching TV?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: They just keep saying the same things. She stares above her at the stars.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It looks so peaceful. A beat as he joins her staring at the night sky.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: The only reason I joined astronomy club was because of you. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: You liked the stars and I figured if you liked them they must be worth looking at.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: That's so nice. This is too close for them, too emotional.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: We got invited to the White House.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Of course. You're an important person now.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: We're going to see the launch with the President. My whole family.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: That's so neat.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Yeah. She smiles, he can be very disarming.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You've changed.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: No, I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Your braces.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: (he grins, no braces) I got them off today. They don't know what to say. Look up again to the stars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pleasant house near Houston. The backyard is filled with about FORTY PEOPLE, THE ASTRONAUTS, THEIR FAMILY, including their PARENTS and their CHILDREN. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 72A CONTINOED
dialogues.text: Running around are TEN OR TWELVE CHILDREN. The CAMERA tracks through the cluster of people, and we hear packets of conversation. The mood, fueled by beer an chips, is happy. Music plays in the backyard speakers. MIKHAIL TULCHINSKY is with TWO VERY PRETTY WOMEN.

dialogues.speaker: PRETTY WOMAN
dialogues.text: A nuclear reactor in space? Isn't that dangerous?

dialogues.speaker: TULCHINSKY
dialogues.text: No, no, no. This is all Russian design, Russian science, the same people who designed Chernobyl. He waits for the response he wanted, horror.

dialogues.speaker: TULCHINSKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, Chernobyl almost worked. And the camera goes to: SIMON and his fiancee, WENDY. She's showing off her diamond ring to another GROUP OF WIVES AND FRIENDS.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Wendy, I'm going to marry you, but the day we get back I can't just go to the church.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: The church will come to you, Simon. You're all invited. The camera finds GUS PARTENZA, with ANDREA BAKER, and her husband, DAVID, and their toddlers, BRITTANY and ALICIA. David holds the squirming Brittany.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What happens when you set off the bombs? Baker tries to answer, but Brittany squirms away. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Partenza a 49B.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Well, as, long as we plant the bombs... We have seven hours... Brittany! Brittany, come back here... As long as we plant the bombs and... Brittany... nswers for her.

dialogues.speaker: PARTENZA
dialogues.text: We have seven hours to plant the bombs and get off the surface before the sun heats it up. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED, (3)
dialogues.text: We leave them and find Monash and his wife MARIETTE. He is seated, she is standing and he is talking to the Baby in her very large belly. As he narrates, he follows the curvature of her belly to her breasts.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: Oren Junior! Here are your orders: upon your first entering into earth's atmosphere, proceed directly along the exterior of the mothership to the twin storage tanks for refueling.

dialogues.speaker: MARIETTE
dialogues.text: He's not a rocket-ship... he's a Baby, Oren, your Baby, our Baby.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: I know. They kiss. Brittany, free again, runs past us leading the camera to Tanner, talking to his two grown sons, DWIGHT a STEVE. They're both in uniform.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: When my father went to war in 1942, he didn't see me or your grandmother for three years. I was eight when he left. You boys were what, four and six when I went to the moon? (they nod) You saw me go into space seven times, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: DWIGHT
dialogues.text: Yessir...

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: And I came back every time, didn't

dialogues.speaker: I
dialogues.text: (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT' D)
dialogues.text: (they nod) Your mother and I used to play a game when she was still alive. The game was, if there was a chance I might not be coming back, she wouldn't say it, and I wouldn't say it. But this time, I want to say it to you.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT' D)
dialogues.text: (a beat) This time I probably won't be coming back. You know that?

dialogues.speaker: SONS
dialogues.text: (quietly) ...Yessir... The three men stare at each other. Don't see Mitch Hefter come up behind them.

dialogues.speaker: HEFTER
dialogues.text: Another beer?

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Thanks. You remember my boys don't you, Mitch?

dialogues.speaker: HEFTER
dialogues.text: (handshakes all around) Sure I do... A LITTLE GIRL SNAPS their picture.- Tanner smiles, wraps an arm around his two boys.

dialogues.speaker: HEFTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What'd you think of the crew?

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Heroes all. The finest group I've ever had the privilege of serving with.

dialogues.speaker: HEFTER
dialogues.text: Off the record. Tanner looks to his sons, then:

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: They've been trained in ways I'll never understand.: They're smarter and in better shape than we ever were in the old days. They're sober, they're serious. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (looks to his sons) I guess I'd be a little happier about this whole thing if I thought that any of them were as scared as I am.

dialogues.speaker: HEFTER
dialogues.text: They're not afraid of dying, they're afraid of screwing up on TV. Two CATERERS wheel out an immense cake in the shape of th earth. People APPLAUD, the children are dazzled.

dialogues.speaker: HEFTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fish, would you do the honor? We see that Monash is uncomfortable with Tanner getting the spotlight. Mariette settles him. Tanner raises the knife to the cake. A few people with cameras are ready to snap the picture. He hesitates. Hefter motions with his hand: Cut the cake. Tanner raises the knife. He can't.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Is this supposed to be a joke? Cutting up the earth, is that supposed to give us good luck?

dialogues.speaker: HEFTER
dialogues.text: Fish, do it for the kids. We see how desperately the children want the cake. They'v surrounded Tanner. Everyone is watching him. He takes the knife and uses it like a trowel, smearing the icing until everything is a swirl. He looks to the children.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: You know what this is? A Kid shakes his head, no, very soberly.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's the comet. And what do we do to comets? He plunges a hand into the comet, and the children do the same, laughing. Hefter gives him a look, and the Astronau are unhappy with his sudden mania. Tanner sees the earth destroyed, the coast lines wrecked.

dialogues.text: The President, Entrekin, aides, Leo, and the Biedermans, watch the Shuttle launch on TV. Jenny's on a stand-up in front of a large NASA wall mural.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: We're now only minutes away from the launch of the Shuttle Atlantis (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: and the beginning of the historic Messiah Mission...

dialogues.speaker: HEFTER, (VO)
dialogues.text: Okay, all flight controllers, we're at T minus 3 minutes and counting... give it a close look.

dialogues.text: APU's look good, LOX and LH2 are pressurized. A shot of the Atlantis on its pad. The President makes his way to a glass jar of M&Ms and grabs a handful.

dialogues.text: Who's voice are we hearing now, Jenny?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (VO)
dialogues.text: Tim, that's Flight Director Mitch Hefter, former Gemini and Apollo astronaut... Leo tries to concentrate on the TV but can't help staring at his surroundings, the Presidential Seal, the desk.

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: Who's your book agent, Leo?

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: You're writing a book about this aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: (not sure where the leader of the Free World and the Commander in Chief is going) I have a book report due on Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: So you're not going to write a book?

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: What kind of American are you? You're famous and you don't want to get rich from it? You'll kill the economy. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: I'm issuing an executive order, Leo; when the President makes a bad joke, would you laugh?

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: (smiling) Yessir.

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: (referring to M&M's) Green?

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Blue.

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: Everything's is going to be okay, you know that, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Yessir.

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: Thank you. (the countdown is past ten) Here we go.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT FLIGHT DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Flight, we're go for autosequence.

dialogues.speaker: HEFTER
dialogues.text: Good luck and Godspeed, Atlantis.

dialogues.speaker: CAPE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: . Three... Two... One... Liftoff! The Shuttle lifts off the pad in a burst of painfully hot light. The big ship ROARS above, tearing into the night sky. Everyone in the room watches, and then applauds. The President puts his hands on Leo's shoulders.

dialogues.text: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Well, and what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I've been busy, and I haven't been paying attention to you.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I've been busy, too. This is the last issue of the magazine...

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: (lightly mocking Jenny's shock) Yes! The advertisers are calling, up and canceling. Why would anyone support a magazine devoted to old, expensive, beautiful things when all the attractive young women are on television spreading panic?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: That's not fair! The news is good, the mission is going to succeed.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I stopped watching the news. Does anything I do have any effect on anything that happens in space?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I mean... but... the whole world is watching.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: The whole world minus one. For years I've always been a little ashamed of what I do, worrying all day about whether this piece of furniture is real or a fake, or whether that painting is better than this painting. No, now that no one has the time to buy antiques, old, beautiful things, it Means that I actually have a sacred purpose. It's like the Russians who saved the old palaces when the Germans were coming; they didn't have time to cart everything away, so they chopped out a bit of the floor and cut away a few feet of (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: curtain, and when the war was over they built everything back from the pieces. I'm saving the pieces now, keeping a record. If the comet does hit, and they want to know what the world looked like, they'll be looking at the work I'm doing today.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Mother, listen to me! The comet is going to be turned away and everyone is going to be so relieved that they'll spend money like the world really is coming to an end.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: That's pretty to think so.  83 56.

dialogues.text: You're right on the numbers, Atlantis. On the monitors, a huge docking device fills the view. But Tanner's not watching, he's staring out the side at something they're passing but we can't see. Whistles softly.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: ...Jesus, that's big... Partenza and Tulchinsky follow his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: PARTENZA
dialogues.text: Whoa...no shit...

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Contact in three meters ...two...one... (a little nudge) We're here. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.text: Well done, Atlantis... Monash turns around, grins.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: Wow. Tanner still staring out the porthole.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: ...Sweet mother of God.

dialogues.text: WE PULL AWAY from Tanner in the window, out past the Shuttle, past the spindly, solar to find --

dialogues.text: Tulchinsky is in the cargo hold, checking the loaded nuke in zero gravity.: Monash is on the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH, (ON COM)
dialogues.text: How we doing, Mikhail?

dialogues.speaker: TULCHINSKY
dialogues.text: Nukes prepped and stowed.

dialogues.text: Let's get moving. Tulchinsky grabs a handhold, pulls himself along the carg compartment, through the hatch into the living quarters. Past the toilet, shower, galley. Pulls himself into the aft compartment. It's tight but functional, conduit, switching panels, bundles containing thousands of wires. Monash is up front with Baker and Simon. Tanner buckling up in back, Tulchinsky sets himself down with Partenza in front of a complex set of monitors and oscillators that bank up to the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: PARTENZA
dialogues.text: Nervous? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Just not used to the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: PARTENZA
dialogues.text: It's not so bad. View stinks. Monash turns in his seat, looks back at Tulchinsky.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: Colonel, let's see what this baby can do. Tulchinsky grins. Punches commands into his keyboard.

dialogues.speaker: PARTENZA
dialogues.text: Hope you're right about this thing working, Mikhail.

dialogues.speaker: TULCHINSKY
dialogues.text: Just between you and me...

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Oh, shit...

dialogues.speaker: TULCHINSKY
dialogues.text: Orion burn in ten...nine...eight... The rapidly moving pattern on the oscillator gets closer and closer to a straight line.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: Hold onto your hats, boys and girls.

dialogues.text: It's not my hat I'm worried about.

dialogues.text: The nuclear reaction EXPLODES against the backplate, lighting up the darkness with a tremendous, BLINDING puls The Messiah takes off like a bat out of hell, CATAPULTED out into space. Disappears among the stars.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: There it is! He steps back so she can look. She looks.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: It's beautiful Leo... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.text: Now she takes his hand. Still looking.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: What if it doesn't work? What if the world ends?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: The world is not going to end.

dialogues.speaker: LEO

dialogues.speaker: SARAH

dialogues.text: Think about it, maybe the comet is a great way to die. No time to think, squished like a bug. I'd rather die like that than by drowning.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Leo!

dialogues.speaker: LEO

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I don't want to talk about this, Leo. It makes me sad. It makes me think about all the things I'll never get a chance to do... Shakespeare in London and ... hiking in Colorado and... even... Disneyworld, just a nice time with my Mom and Dad and... and love. I'll never get any of that now. So just shut up.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: It's not your fault. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're too young. It's all wrong now, because I don't have time for you to figure things out, I don't have three years for you to wake up and know what you feel about me.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: That's just it, you have to ask. Because you're still just a little kid, part of you. And if the world is coming to an end, we don't have time for that.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: what?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (exasperated) You love me and I love you And she runs away from him.

dialogues.speaker: CARGO BAY
dialogues.text: Tulchinsky, Baker and Partenza load aluminum encased bomb into the MOLES, already mounted on the SLED. Metal, wires radioactive warnings. It's demanding work with no gravity

dialogues.speaker: MONASH, (ON COM)
dialogues.text: How's it coming? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Inserting the last nuke now. When it CLICKS in place, the digital readout BLINKS ALIVE

dialogues.speaker: MSNBC CONFERENCE ROOM 102
dialogues.text: Stuart leads the staff meeting. Ira, Worth, Marianne Beth, Tim, Jenny. Jenny sits at the grown-up table, quiet lost in her own thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Beth, White House reactions. Marianne, all the world watching. We have enough satellite space?

dialogues.speaker: WORTH
dialogues.text: Seventy-eight up-links.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Tim, Mission Control in Houston. (Tim looks up, surprised) Ira, the science guys lined up?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: If they've got a PhD, we own them.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: This is the most important story of our lives. Let's not fuck it up. The end of the meeting, people start out. Jenny looks up.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: ...Stuart? What about me? People stop, is she finally going to get her comeuppance?

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: You're on the anchor desk and don't you ever hold back a story for two days.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry but, the President...

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: The hell with the President. He has no right making deals with a reporter who has no authority to accept his terms. I probably would have held the story, but that would have been my decision and not yours. And I would have protected you. It was your scoop. You own the story. Don't do that again. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Stuart.

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Yeah. Okay.  63.

dialogues.speaker: THE MESSIAH 103
dialogues.text: Monash lines the Messiah up with the tail of the comet, following a computer path in the cockpit.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Auto trajectory, two thousand feet, R-dot .3, 5 X, 2 Y... Monash guides it expertly, a high tech video game.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A thousand feet, point 3, 3 X, one- point-five Y... (a beat) Go for auto trajectory. Monash reaches up, locks it on with a BEEP.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're on... Disengage the Orion.

dialogues.speaker: TULCHINSKY
dialogues.text: Orion disengaged. You're on chemical propellant.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: Look, Fish, I can do this if you want. Monash slides out of his seat, let's Tanner slide past.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: I'll keep that in mind. Monash goes. Tanner pulls out a decades old shot of a mother and seven year old son, sticks it on the console.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: On the Mississippi River, in Mark Twain's time, there were riverboat pilots who only knew a few miles of the river. Conditions changed so much, you couldn't know the whole trip. Floods, sandbars, fallen logs, it was alla riverboat pilot could do to know his little piece of the puzzle.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: What the hell is he talking about? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PARTENZA
dialogues.text: Summer job he had last century. Tanner finishes strapping himself in.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: For the next few hours, this is my ship. (flips toggles) Starting the approach.

dialogues.speaker: THE CARGO BAY 105A
dialogues.text: The now fully suited astronauts check their gear in buddy groups. Tulchinsky with Partenza. Simon with Monash.

dialogues.speaker: TULCHINSKY
dialogues.text: Helmet lights.

dialogues.speaker: PARTENZA
dialogues.text: Your sublimator looks good, Mick.

dialogues.speaker: TULCHINSKY
dialogues.text: Visors down. They test the gold face shields on their helmets. Lights mounted on the side of the helmets CLICK on.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (ON COM)
dialogues.text: Disengaging auto...now. I'm eyeballs out from here on in.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: How come that doesn't make me feel better?

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Cameras on.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE COCKPIT 105B
dialogues.text: Baker checks the helmet cams. Each monitor marked with a name. WE SEE the cargo bay from the HELMET POVs.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Okay, we're going live. Mikhail, wave for the folks back home. Mikhail waves as he floats around.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Andy, I need you on the laser. She looks up, Christ. Ahead, a floating three dimensional mine field of every imaginable size of rock. Tanner nudges one, THUD. It's like playing dodge ball with really big, slow rocks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: My God, look at the size of that thing. It's as big as a house.  65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny is walking across the studio with an ASSISTANT.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Your father is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Tell him I'm not here.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR, (ON STUDIO COM)
dialogues.text: Jenny, forty-five seconds...

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: That's great. You're on live, Jenny. Jenny gets into her chair.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR, (ON STUDIO COM)
dialogues.text: In ten, nine, eight... The Assistant goes to a phone.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Thank you. Jason is looking at the TV, as the final logo sequence an music of the intro to a MSNBC SPECIAL REPORT... Then:

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Tonight we have the first pictures from the Messiah as it begins its descent to the comet Wolf- Biederman...

dialogues.speaker: MSNBC STUDIO 108
dialogues.text: The fuzzy helmet cam shots of the astronauts waiting in the sled are intercut with the Messiah's approach shots o the comet. Bobby approaches Eric in the wings, whispers.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: How's she doing?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Okay so far...

dialogues.speaker: BIEDERMAN LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: The Hotchners and Biedermans watch MSNBC together. Vicky Hotchner now very pregnant. Leo and Sarah hold hands. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE MESSIAH COCKPIT 110
dialogues.text: Tanner's looking for a place to land. There's lightning, floating debris. They BANG around, the emergency lights FLICKER on, then off. The sun's just setting on the surfa below, the outgassing only beginning to settle down.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Use primary thrusters.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ... She's scared, they're taking quite a beating from the jet

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: How are we doing back there? On the helmet cams we see the boys bouncing around in bac it doesn't look fun strapped to a sled. Like riding a bull.

dialogues.speaker: PARTENZA, (ON COM)
dialogues.text: Peachy...

dialogues.speaker: COMET SURFACE
dialogues.text: The Messiah approaches a small flat zone wedged between a crater and a cliff. The long shadows of the sunset stretc across the rugged landscape below.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE COCKPIT 112
dialogues.text: Rocks bounce off the windshield and hull.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Hold on tight. Descent rate. The Messiah descends over the comet, outgassing jets send up streams of fine carbon, obscuring the landing site. The BANGING and CHOP is getting worse.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Three feet per second... two...

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Fire tether pitons.

dialogues.speaker: COMET SURFACE 113
dialogues.text: Umbrella shaped pitons shoot out from the underside of th ship, blast down into the surface. The cables pull TAUT as winches draws them down to the comet's surface and ont the spindly landing gear. A high speed surface jet FIRES, shoving the bow port (front left) section of the ship up and YANKING the piton up out of the ground, with a SNAP.  67.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE COCKPIT 114
dialogues.text: The Messiah BUCKS up from the force, tilts precariously back. The horizon disappears below.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Whoa... Tanner's trying to hold it. Baker checks frantically.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Tether two, not engaged!

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE MESSIAH 115
dialogues.text: It noses up, a horse rearing back with three legs tied to the ground. The stern CRUNCHES LOUDLY into the surface.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE COCKPIT 116
dialogues.text: The astronauts cling to the sled on the helmet cams.

dialogues.speaker: PARTENZA, (ON COM)
dialogues.text: What the fuck was that? Tanner tries to hold the nose up as it dips to the right.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Override on the forward jets. Baker is flipping overhead switches.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: You got 'em...we crunched the aft pod.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE MESSIAH 117
dialogues.text: It edges down to the left front where the tether came loo It's a meter from the surface, going to slam hard. A jet fires from the undercarriage. The ship slows but still HITS.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE COCKPIT 118
dialogues.text: The bronc riders get tossed around some more on the helme cams as they rock back to the stern again, a tethered teetertotter.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Cross-feed aft. I need all the jets.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Cross-feed aft...pressure's holding.  119 120 67A.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE MESSIAH 119
dialogues.text: They fire the starboard aft jet. The ship disappears in t ejecta of the comet, steam and carbon dust. Slowly levels out, the three remaining tethers finally going. TAUT.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE COCKPIT 120
dialogues.text: Baker watches the artificial horizon on the instrument array. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: She's leveling out...

dialogues.speaker: PARTENZA
dialogues.text: Pretty much like the simulator back at Johnson, huh boys?

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch doesn't know what he's doing.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE COCKPIT 122
dialogues.text: Tanner still has the stick in a death lock. Baker looks shell shocked. Holy shit... A beat.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Houston, this is Messiah, we've landed.

dialogues.speaker: UNIVERSAL CITY WALK
dialogues.text: A CHEERING CROWD watches the huge pixel vision screen. A fuzzy, space transmitted image of Tanner and Baker.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: ...we've landed...

dialogues.speaker: THE BIEDERMAN'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: The families cheer, applaud. Sarah hugs Leo.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Oh, thank god...

dialogues.speaker: COCKPIT 125
dialogues.text: Tanner and Baker work. Locking in computer coordinates.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Depressurizing bay.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Opening payload doors. Don't let that little bit of gravity down there go to your heads.

dialogues.speaker: UNDER THE MESSIAH
dialogues.text: The huge doors open and the Astronauts float down. We see what is ahead: The dead terrain of the comet. The sled floats a few feet above the shale strewn surface

dialogues.speaker: IN THE COCKPIT
dialogues.text: Tanner reaches up above him, HITS a button.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Start the clock. A red LED SNAPS on, above it an embossed tag "Sunrise". It's counting down, 6:47:14...:13...:12...

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SURFACE
dialogues.text: A small blast from the chemical propellant and they fly b with the sled, skimming over the surface.

dialogues.speaker: PARTENZA
dialogues.text: Looks like all you did was dent a fender, Fish. Dad's gonna be mad when we get home. The comet is mostly very old terrain, worn smooth by eons of travel, hilly in places, craters. All sizes of rocks float past them, have to be batted away. The weather is made even stranger by the frequent gas lightning above. Graphic heads up displays are projected onto the inside glass of their helmets, indicating the composition of the substrata layers beneath them.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE COCKPIT
dialogues.text: A cross-sectional computer image of the comet emerges. Tanner and Baker watch as computer images are joined by overlays of geological schematics detailing fault lines and possibilities for nuclear warhead placement. The clock counts 5:21:39... The computer stops, zeros in. Circles coordinates.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: We've got your first location. Range two meters above point Alpha 16, bearing 224. 128 129 130 131 132  70.

dialogues.speaker: BIEDERMAN LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Jane is sleeping in her mother's lap. All watch Jenny on MSNBC, doing VO commentary for the footage from the comet

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (VO ON SET)
dialogues.text: What we're looking at now is...God, isn't that an amazing picture? They're setting the MOLEs in place now, and the MOLEs are, well, they're what they sound like. The MOLEs are drilling machines that burrow to a depth of one hundred meters, and then they wait to be detonated. Of course the MOLEs in your backyard don't carry 5,000 kiloton warheads. Although it feels like they do sometimes, doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: ON THE COMET SURFACE
dialogues.text: The MOLE comes to life, the auger head digs slowly into the surface. Monash reels out control line.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Ooh, look at that baby dig.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: Fish, tell the guys at JSC their mole works like a charm.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Like butter baby.

dialogues.speaker: PARTENZA
dialogues.text: Go get em, boy.

dialogues.speaker: MESSIAH COCKPIT 135
dialogues.text: Baker and Tanner work at the computer, get the mapping coordinates for the final 2 MOLES. Look unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Dammit...

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Christ, that's over four miles away. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tanner goes to the helmet cam monitors.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: The computer's calculated the last two MOLE, locations, guys. Range 4 miles. Target One: bearing 166. Target Two: bearing 168. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 136 137 138 On Simon's helmet cam we see Monash look up.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH, (ON MONITORS)
dialogues.text: How long's that going to take?

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: At least an hour. There's a beat. Everybody knows what that means.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH, (ON MONITORS)
dialogues.text: An hour? (dry WASP) An hour? Darling, that gives me no time at all to go home, get dressed and be at the theater on time for the curtain. What were we thinking when we made these reservations? Tanner and Baker look at the clock. 1:49:47...:46...

dialogues.speaker: A SMALL MONITOR ROOM AT JSC 136
dialogues.text: Monitors, a few sofas, very governmental. The families of the astronauts watch MSNBC, hold each others hands. MSNB has added a sunrise clock on screen, not very comforting. Jenny's on camera, interviewing Dr. Van Sertma.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: What happens if they don't get off of the surface in time?

dialogues.speaker: VAN SERTMA, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: The sun striking the comet will cause the temperature to rise three hundred and fifty degrees in only a few minutes and activate the high speed gas jets. If that happens it'll be like trying to work ina mine field.

dialogues.speaker: COMET SURFACE
dialogues.text: Monash and Simon angle the sled to the final location.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: We're on Target Two, Messiah.

dialogues.speaker: ABOUT TWENTY YARDS AWAY 138
dialogues.text: Partenza and Tulchinsky drill at Target One. A trail of debris rises out of the hole, shoved up by the MOLE.

dialogues.speaker: PARTENZA
dialogues.text: How's our time?  71A.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Getting tight. 36:30. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: It's taking too long.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE COMET'S SURFACE 140
dialogues.text: Simon and Monash Work above their final MOLE hole. Feed out the control line, read the digital depth LED.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: MOLE 4 running true, at 26 meters.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch...

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: what?

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: It's stuck.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH AND SIMON 141
dialogues.text: Monash looks down the hole. All he can see is debris.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Try backing it up.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MESSIAH 142
dialogues.text: Tanner and Baker watch all this on the helmet cams.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: What's your depth?

dialogues.speaker: MONASH, (ON COM)
dialogues.text: Sixteen meters.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: That enough?

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: No, it'll just blow pieces off the surface.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: That's not deep enough.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH, (ON COM)
dialogues.text: No shit, thanks for the insight. Blow three pitons, back the sled off.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SURFACE 143
dialogues.text: Simon releases all but one piton, shoves the sled away.  73.

dialogues.speaker: PARTENZA
dialogues.text: Mole three at depth. Coming your way. Simon screws a pitch into the surface, attaches a line to hold him in place. Monash is using the MOLE control line as a tether, they're stirring up carbon as they work.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: I'm going in.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: The hole?!

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: See if I can free it up. Monash goes in feet first, using the line as a rope.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MESSIAH 144
dialogues.text: They watch Monash's helmet cam as he descends into the hole. Like dropping into a small well, his helmet lights illuminate the dark, veiny walls close around him.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: How's my time?

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Another six minutes and they won't have time to get back to us. A beat. Tanner leaps for the pilot's seat.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Blow the tethers. She realizes what he's thinking.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: We go get them and we may not have enough fuel to get back off the surface.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Blow the goddamn tethers!

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Calculate exactly how much prop we need to get off this rock! Shut us down when we hit it. She TYPES into a keyboard. Numbers rush by.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Got it!

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE MESSIAH
dialogues.text: 74 A BEEP. The aft thrusters ignite and the ship moves away fast.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE HOLE
dialogues.text: Tulchinsky and Partenza arrive. Monash works his way down to the top of the MOLE. Braces himself against the walls, gets his feet on it.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: Give it some juice. The MOLE shimmies a little, shakes, but doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hold up. It stops, Monash rocks it back and forth with his boots.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Try backing it up again.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MESSIAH
dialogues.text: Baker's computer BEEPS.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: That's it.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Little more, little more... She looks at the fuel usage whizzing by. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Shut it down!

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: They always put extra in the tanks! Baker leans across, shuts it down. A beat, Tanner knows she was right.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We have a visual? Across the valley. The yellow sled.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Straight ahead one hundred yards.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MOLE HOLE 151
dialogues.text: Monash kicks and shakes the MOLE, tugs up on the feed lin

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: ...Come on... you bastard. Time?

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: 11:04. Figured we'd better pick you kids up after school. Check your six...100 yards.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SURFACE 152
dialogues.text: Partenza looks, sees the Messiah hovering in the distance Notices the sun striking the hilltops on the other side o the valley. Checks over his shoulder at the coming dawn.

dialogues.speaker: PARTENZA
dialogues.text: I think we'd better hurry, boys.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH, (ON COM)
dialogues.text: One more time, Mark.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE HOLE 153
dialogues.text: The MOLE struggles, RUMBLES and then...begins to DIG.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: It's going!

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MESSIAH 154
dialogues.text: Baker stares at the dawn horizon.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: I don't think they've got 10 minutes. The sun is rising between two mountains, it's going to pour straight down into the valley, right where they are.  155 156 157 158 159 76.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SURFACE 155
dialogues.text: Debris is shooting up from the hole.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: MOLEs at forty-two meters.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (ON COM)
dialogues.text: Sun's rising behind you, coming up fast. Partenza sees the rapidly shrinking shadows. They move much faster than earth. Everywhere it strikes, the surfac gets unstable. Rocks fly, jets explode.

dialogues.speaker: TULCHINSKY
dialogues.text: Face shields down! The three men on the surface down their gold shields.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE HOLE 156
dialogues.text: Monash is pummeled with debris shooting up from the diggi MOLE. Pulling himself up the control line as fast as he can. No way he has time for his face shield in this mess.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SURFACE 157
dialogues.text: The sun marches closer and closer. Now only thirty yards away, jets explode like mortars in the heat.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: MOLE's at depth and armed!

dialogues.speaker: ON THE MESSIAH 158
dialogues.text: Tanner and Baker watch the sun's approach with alarm.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Get the hell out of there!

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SURFACE 159
dialogues.text: Partenza screams back into his headset.

dialogues.speaker: PARTENZA
dialogues.text: Oren's still in the hole! Simon stares into the hole, sees the top of Monash's helm

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Another three meters!

dialogues.speaker: PARTENZA
dialogues.text: Oh, Christ... The sun is only yards away. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Oren, come on, go...go...!

dialogues.speaker: IN THE HOLE 160
dialogues.text: Monash grabs the line. Pulls hard, propelling himself up much too fast, like a missile. Shooting out onto the --

dialogues.speaker: SURFACE 161
dialogues.text: Heading straight up into orbit. Partenza grabs his passin boot and is pulled along until Partenza's tether catches. They bob in space, the light gravity slowly bringing them back down. Monash staring out in shock.

dialogues.speaker: PARTENZA
dialogues.text: Get us down! Simon grabs the tether line, pulls them back, spinning them slowly as they come. Partenza looks up, realizes.

dialogues.speaker: PARTENZA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oren, your face shield! Monash looks down, what? Just as his face rotates full into the blinding sun. Screams in pain.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: Ahhhhhh...AAHHHH... 1!!! Monash claws at the helmet, trying to get to his blinded eyes. They get him back to the surface, SLAM his shield DOWN, drag him behind them to the sled. The sun hits them as they FLOP Monash on top, lash him down. The ground begins to boil and steam.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My eyes...oh god...my eyes...

dialogues.speaker: TULCHINSKY
dialogues.text: Gus, come on! Come on...! It's only yards around the sled to Partenza's seat but th sunblasted surface is cracking, EXPLODING. He's trying to cross a jet minefield.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (ON COM)
dialogues.text: Get out of there! Partenza dodges one, sees a clear spot, steps and BOOM! A jet explodes into his chest. Rocketing him up like a huma cannonball.

dialogues.speaker: TULCHINSKY
dialogues.text: Gus...Gus...! Partenza's sling-shot out into space hundreds of feet.  162

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: we're losing one! Tanner leaps to look. Partenza's helmet cam has a quickly diminishing view of the comet below.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He's got escape velocity. A thousand feet and climbing.

dialogues.speaker: PARTENZA IN SPACE 162A
dialogues.text: He watches the comet recede.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SURFACE 163
dialogues.text: They're looking up, frozen. Jets EXPLODING all around.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (ON COM)
dialogues.text: Mikhail, Mark, get the hell out of there! Simon fires the sled and they head for the Messiah.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MESSIAH 164
dialogues.text: The sun works its way across the valley, closer and close to the Messiah.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Houston, all MOLES are at depth, nukes hot and ready. We lost Partenza to explosive outgassing. Monash is injured.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE SMALL ROOM AT JSC 165
dialogues.text: The families stare at the TV, in shook. Hold each other. The sun clock now blinks 0:00 on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: MSNBC STUDIO 166
dialogues.text: Jenny and the MSNBC staff watch the Messiah pictures.

dialogues.speaker: UNDER THE MESSIAH 167
dialogues.text: Tulchinsky helps load the GROANING Monash onto a hoist.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Retract hoist one! Monash is pulled up into the Cargo bay. The sun now fully striking the Messiah. Rocks and jets shoot all over the place. Tulchinsky SNAPS onto another hoist. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: TULCHINSKY
dialogues.text: Retract four! Tulchinsky starts up. Simon connects himself. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: Retract two! The hoist starts and BOOM! A rock SLAMS into Simon's forearm, hard. Sends him swinging like a kid on a rope over a river SLAMMING into the underbelly.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE COCKPIT 168
dialogues.text: The hull vibrates from the rocks like POPPING corn.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Firing primary thrusters.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Payload doors are still open!

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Close them as we go!

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Is Oren with you, Simon? Is Oren on the ship?

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: We're going now!

dialogues.speaker: UNDER THE MESSIAH 169
dialogues.text: The ship fires its thrusters. Lifts up, the men still dangling below.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE COCKPIT 170
dialogues.text: It's choppy. Rocks BANG. Tanner steers as best he can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ship flies off.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CARGO BAY 171
dialogues.text: The three men are being reeled in through the now closing doors. A final rock EXPLODES up through the doors, SHATTE a light. Tulchinsky releases himself, swings Monash over safety.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
