dialogues.text: I think my arm's broken... Tulchinsky reels Simon in. Releases him.  T9A.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Repressurize the cargo bay.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Cargo bay repressurized. Tulchinsky comes in out of his EVA suit.

dialogues.speaker: TULCHINSKY
dialogues.text: We have to go get Gus.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: There's not enough time.

dialogues.speaker: TULCHINSKY
dialogues.text: He's going to die out there! Something SLAMS into the underbelly, sends them careening off to the left as Tanner wrestles the stick. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: TULCHINSKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We can still find him, he has a beacon!

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: I don't have time to argue with you. Sit down and shut-up. The ship BUCKS and SLAMS through debris.

dialogues.speaker: TULCHINSKY
dialogues.text: Turn it on! Turn on the fucking locator!

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: We barely have enough propellant to get out of the coma!

dialogues.speaker: TULCHINSKY
dialogues.text: We can't just leave him. We have to go back.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: If we go for Gus, we all die...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monash hears this.

dialogues.speaker: TULCHINSKY, (ON COM)
dialogues.text: We can't just leave him in space.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: Tulchinsky, listen to Tanner. It's his ship now.

dialogues.speaker: 172B IN THE COCKPIT
dialogues.text: Tulchinsky slowly lowers himself into a seat. Leans his head back, exhausted, tears run down his face.

dialogues.speaker: MSNBC STUDIO 173
dialogues.text: It's very quiet on the set. Finally, Jenny:

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: This has been such an indescribable day, hasn't it? Where do you begin? The Messiah has lifted safely off the comet, and so we're cheering for that, but Gus Partenza is dead. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: His photo 80A. 173 appears behind her.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He was...everyone who knew him loved him. Even more than that, they liked him. It's hard to report the news when you're torn between excitement and sadness. I can't even imagine how they feel on the Messiah.

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR MESSIAH 174
dialogues.text: The astronauts are floating silently in the living quarte Monash is lying on the table, Baker works on his eyes with the med kit. It's painful. Tanner speaks quietly to Baker

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Bad?  81.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Her look says it all. Tanner goes back to checking Simon. Partenza begins to cry softly.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Robin watches in silence.

dialogues.speaker: UNIVERSAL
dialogues.text: The crowd

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: They're going to set off the bombs in thirteen minutes, well, less than thirteen now. (beat, she's reflecting) We're supposed to see a large increase in the comet's brightness as dust from the explosion is hit by the rays of the sun.

dialogues.speaker: STUDIOS CITY WALK
dialogues.text: watches Jenny on MSNBC.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: (she's looking off camera) Do we know if that's going to be visible to the naked eye or only on telescopes? ... We don't know. We do? Oh... naked eye. You'll see the brightness. We will, we'll see it together.

dialogues.speaker: MSNBC STUDIO 177
dialogues.text: On the monitors we see images from around the Messiah.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Prepare to remove safeties and fire.

dialogues.speaker: TULCHINSKY, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Safeties removed...

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: After the death of Dr. Gus Partenza and with Oren Monash injured, (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Spurgeon Tanner is now in command of the mission.

dialogues.speaker: BIEDERMAN HOME 178
dialogues.text: The Biedermans and Hotchners are still watching together. The comet as seen from the Messiah fills the screen. JENNY (CONTD) Okay, this is what's coming next: the radiation burst is going to wipe out the transmission from the Messiah, just for a minute, maybe a little longer, so don't panic when the picture goes out. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE MESSTAH 179
dialogues.text: Tanner, Baker and Tulchinsky are now up front.

dialogues.speaker: TULCHINSKY
dialogues.text: Weapons armed. Tanner looks over at Partenza's helmet cam, only space in and out of heavy static.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: We're detonating the bombs now, Gus.

dialogues.speaker: PARTENZA
dialogues.text: ...okay... He's very distant. None of them know what to say. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Unlock firing switches. Tanner and Baker unlock switch guards, exposing red "fire switches, side by side in the console.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Three... two... one... NOW.

dialogues.speaker: THE COMET 180
dialogues.text: Light shoots from the MOLE holes, then BLINDING WHITE.

dialogues.speaker: MSNBC STUDIOS 181
dialogues.text: The screen fills with static. Tanner's breaking up.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Weapons detonation... confirmed... 10:04, Zulu ...time, 24 Augu...,

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MESSIAH 182
dialogues.text: Debris is hurled from the comet. SLAMS into the Messiah, shuts down the electrical system. FLIPS them sideways, BURSTING lights and a stern cargo WINDOW. ALARMS sound.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Decompression in area six! Tulchinsky leaps up out of his chair, pulls himself along the blender that's now the Messiah's interior, SLAMS agai pipes, floors, ceilings. THROWS himself against the cargo hatch door, trying to close it and not be sucked out.  183 184 185 186 187 83.

dialogues.speaker: MSNBC STUDIOS
dialogues.text: The static is beginning to clear.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Now we're just waiting for the picture to come back. This is hard. Twenty seconds. Slowly, the view of the comet from the Messiah returns. The comet's surrounded with debris, breaking into two pieces, one five times larger than the other. A huge CHEE erupts, the staff CLAPS, CRIES, they hug each other. Beth holds her daughter Caitlin.

dialogues.speaker: CAITLIN
dialogues.text: What happened, Mommy?

dialogues.speaker: UNIVERSAL CITY WALK
dialogues.text: It's Times Square on V-J Day, bedlam, joy.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE MESSIAH
dialogues.text: Tulchinsky struggles the last few inches, gets the suckin hatch door closed, the wheel turned. Smoke, wires exposed Simon extinguishes a small fire. Baker looks to Partenza's helmet cam, only STATIC.

dialogues.speaker: BIEDERMAN HOUSE
dialogues.text: They watch the set, the dust, the two comets in space.

dialogues.speaker: HEFTER, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Messiah, this is Houston... Messiah can you respond... Everyone is elated, hugging, except for Leo. Sarah holds him, tears running down her face, but he's still watching the TV, worried. Slowly, she realizes.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: -Leo...? But he doesn't answer, something's wrong. 183 184 185 186 187  84-85.

dialogues.speaker: 187B WHITE HOUSE OFFICE
dialogues.text: The room's crammed full of electronic gear, computers. Th President, Entrekin, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs SCOTT, other aides and advisors. No one says a word. All are turned toward Bekey, a phone to his ear. Waiting.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN BEKEY
dialogues.text: (into phone) ...Im still here Listens for a long beat. Then hangs up, slowly turns to the President. He doesn't have to say it, they all know. The President stares at his feet, the weight of his job too great today. Then finally, quietly:

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: Your people ready, Morton? (Entrekin nods) General?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. The President nods, heads for the brightly lit Oval Offic next door.

dialogues.speaker: 187C MSNBC
dialogues.text: Champagne, smiles, relieved tears. The President appears on the monitors, his voice cutting through the celebratio

dialogues.speaker: BECK, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Good evening. He takes a long time to say the next thing. The staff quiets, turns to watch. The President's grim expression slowly sucking the joy from the room. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: You know what just happened. There was one big.comet, and now there are two. And they're both headed to earth.

dialogues.speaker: 188A MSNBC STUDIO
dialogues.text: We MOVE SLOWLY through the faces, then onto the long wall of monitors; every station carrying the speech.

dialogues.speaker: BECK, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Let's call the big one Wolf and the smaller piece, Biederman. Wolf is six miles wide, Biederman a mile and a half. Separately or together, they are capable of destroying life as we know it. Wwe have lost communication with the Messiah spacecraft although we continue to track it visually. It left the comet under power and has made course corrections under power. The ship is coming home. We don't know how many are alive. We don't know their condition. He takes a moment. All stare, the words sinking in.

dialogues.speaker: BECK, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Now we have to make some decisions together. What do we do? You have a choice, we have a choice right now. Ever since the comet was discovered, we've been hoping and working for the best, but we've also been planning for the worst. Our strategy has been two-fold. First, our Strategic Missile Command is preparing to coordinate with the Russians a massive strike of Titan missiles to intercept the incoming comets. If we can deflect these comets only two degrees they will bounce harmlessly off of our atmosphere and head out into space...

dialogues.speaker: 188B IN THE BIEDERMAN'S LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: They watch the speech. Sarah clinging to Leo.

dialogues.speaker: BECK, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, the Titans cannot be launched until the comets are (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BECK, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: only a few hours away and while we are confident the Missile attack will succeed, it is only prudent that we now take cautionary steps to insure the continuation of our way of life. To guarantee that there will be enough of us left to rebuild a new world in the unlikely event that the comets do strike the earth...  87.

dialogues.speaker: 188C THE OVAL OFFICE
dialogues.text: The CAMERA moves in slowly on the President.

dialogues.speaker: BECK
dialogues.text: So, in the soft limestone of Missouri, we've been preparing a network of immense caves, and they're almost finished, and we can put a million people in them, and that million people can survive there, underground, for two years, until the air clears and the dust settles. The cave is more than a dormitory, it's our new Noah's Ark: we're storing seeds and seedlings, plants and animals, enough to start over. On August 10, we're going to hold a national lottery...

dialogues.speaker: 188D MSNBC STUDIO
dialogues.text: The faces of people watching; in Times Square, in Chicago Seattle, Houston and San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: BECK, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: A computer will randomly select eight hundred thousand Americans, to join the two hundred thousand scientists, doctors, engineers, teachers, soldiers and artists who have already been chosen. Other countries are preparing similar caves along whatever lines they feel are best to preserve their ways of life. This is ours.

dialogues.speaker: 188E ROBIN'S TOWNHOUSE
dialogues.text: Robin is watching alone.

dialogues.speaker: BECK, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Beginning tonight, and continuing until the crisis passes, I am declaring a state of Martial Law. The Armed Forces and the National Guard are working with local law enforcement. A national curfew begins at midnight tonight. Wherever you are, go home. Stay off the roads after sunset. Crimes against persons or property will be dealt with swiftly and harshly.  87A.

dialogues.speaker: BECK, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: News stations around the nation are being faxed copies of the lottery procedure as we speak and they'll be broadcasting the details to you in a few moments... Worth takes off running for the fax, Ira following.  87B-87C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President takes a break and stops reading copy. He tries to unburden his heart.

dialogues.speaker: BECK, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: I... wish... no, wishing is the wrong word right now. That's not what I mean. Look... I believe in God. A lot of you don't. At times like this, it would just be obscene to use faith as a weapon. But I still want to offer a prayer and I've been trying to find the right one. So let me offer this. It1l pray for our survival, mine included, because I believe that God hears all prayers... but I also believe that sometimes His answer is No. May the Lord lift up His divine countenance upon you, and give you peace. We hear a murmur of AMEN from the people in the Oval Offi or wherever we see this, if on a monitor in MSNBC.

dialogues.speaker: 188H MSNBC STUDIOS
dialogues.text: The Presidential Seal's on the monitors. Jenny's camera light CLICKS ON. She looks off, all formality gone.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Do we have the fax yet, Stuart? (Stuart shakes no) Worth and Ira reappear from the hall, running. Worth carries a sheet of paper overhead, rushes it to the ancho desk. Jenny reads it as the crowded studio waits, silent. JENNY (CONTD) My God... Stuart, how old are you?

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR, (ON STAGE COM)
dialogues.text: Jenny, in five, four...

dialogues.speaker: STUART
dialogues.text: Fifty-five... Her camera light blinks RED. She slowly turns to camera. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: We now have the details of the national lottery. (reads) Those of you who have been pre- selected for the Ark will be notified within the next few minutes...

dialogues.speaker: 188I UNIVERSAL CITY WALK
dialogues.text: We MOVE ACROSS the stunned faces, watching Jenny.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: For the rest, on the night of May 14, those who's social security numbers have been randomly selected by computer will be notified. All phone systems will be turned off for 72 hours beginning on May 13th. The only phones that ring will be those of the people selected...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin watches her daughter deliver the news on TV.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: While some Americans over fifty years of age have been pre-selected for the Ark due to their expertise in a necessary field of study, no men and women over fifty in the general population will be included in the lottery...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chloe gives Jason a look. I don't know about you, but I will survive.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: The evacuation of those who have been selected for the Ark will take no longer than two days beginning on May 18th...

dialogues.speaker: 188L THE BIEDERMAN'S
dialogues.text: The phone RINGS. Everyone looks. It RINGS again.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: ...Hello...?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: During this two day period, no unofficial travel will be permitted. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Those selected will be taken by bus and train to the underground Ark site by military personnel... Ellen hangs up slowly, turns back to the room.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: We've been pre-selected. All turn to Leo, they know why. Chuck leaps up, rushes for the front door.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Chuck...? Where're you going?

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK HOTCHNER
dialogues.text: Our phone! They could be calling! And he's gone. They look among themselves, they all know the Hotchner phone isn't ringing across the street.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: You are being notified now because there is still time to construct your own shelters in basements and backyard pools. Civil Defense teams have been formed in every town and city in America with a population over five thousand. They will distribute supplies and organize group shelters in underground parking facilities and other appropriate sites. Construction plans, equipment lists and locations for securing the necessary provisions along with information on how to grow your own food underground and how to purify water are now available free of charge on the Internet at WwW. FEMA.Com. Jenny stops reading. It's silent. She sets the fax down slowly, looks directly into camera.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's all there is.  87F.

dialogues.speaker: 189A INSIDE THE MESSIAH, (OLD SCENE 198)
dialogues.text: Monash strapped down, gauze covering his eyes, in pain. Tanner and Baker work on the radio, Tulchinsky at the Ori Simon pours over schematics, his arm now roughly splinted (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: The interior camera circuitry is shot. Andy, can we get back into the cargo bay to reroute the video junctions?

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Starboard cargo porthole is blown. We could try to get in there with the EVA's but there's not much left in the life support packs.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: We should be able to raise Houston on the low band when we get closer.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: The Orion still functioning?

dialogues.speaker: TULCHINSKY
dialogues.text: System check was okay, but I don't know about the radiation shielding.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: So, if we fire it up, we beat the comet back to earth, but we may start glowing in the dark. Anybody? A silent beat, then from the corner, hoarsely --

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: Let's go home...

dialogues.speaker: 189B SPACE, (OLD SCENE 199)
dialogues.text: The Orion fires against the backplate, the Messiah picks up tremendous speed, leaves the comets behind.

dialogues.speaker: 189D THE ED SULLIVAN THEATER --NIGHT 189D
dialogues.text: David Letterman on stage, talking to his audience.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID LETTERMAN
dialogues.text: The comets are such great set-ups for a joke, but the problem is that we're the punchline. So here's my last top ten list. Ten: be grateful to the crew of the Messiah for everything they tried to do. Nine: Make peace with your enemies. Eight: Be strong for the children. Seven: Try to help someone you don't know. Six: Don't get crazy. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DAVID LETTERMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Five: Don't be selfish. Four: Love your friends and family. Three: Love your friends and family. Two: Love your friends and family. One: Love your friends and family... Slowly, he walks off stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny walks with Robin.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I have to say it's liberating knowing that I won't be called. I don't think I've ever been happier. I've even stopped smoking.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: What are you going to do with all of the money you save?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Do you know that the National Gallery is saving all of the art? They're shipping it to the caves. I gave them the most beautiful eighteenth century desk from New England, and all of my Sheraton silver. I really felt like I'd protected something when I gave them to the museum. You should see my apartment now. After all these years collecting, there's nothing there now, it's practically Japanese.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: It doesn't seem fair that I got selected. I'm not a doctor, ora scientist.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: People need continuity. You're someone everyone knows. People trust you.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: But I can't help you.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Don't worry about me. I'm going to be happy as long as I know that you're going to live. Have you spoken to your father? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They keep

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (reflexive anger) No.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: The world he lives in is coming to an end, Jenny, you don't want him to die with bitterness in his heart. Talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: why?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: (the answer is coming) When your Father and I were young, I used to think of us as the perfectly matched pair: he was the most graceful man in the world, and he always said I was the most beautiful. But this is what the comet has taught me; that grace is deceptive, and beauty is passing. Don't leave all the unfinished stuff of your life to the comet. Don't let the comet take away your dignity. You're better than that. walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A scientist's being interviewed by Tim at the anchor desk

dialogues.speaker: VAN SERTMA, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: It is impossible to say what is happening on the Messiah now! From the telescopes orbiting the earth, yes, we see evidence that they're using the nuclear propulsion system, but who knows what kind of damage it sustained when the comet exploded? The CAMERA finds Jenny and Eric watching this from a corn of the studio. They drink a couple of beers.

dialogues.speaker: VAN SERTMA, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: The Russians are very pessimistic about this. Radiation contamination, overheating: the Orion system is just as likely to blow up as it is to work.

dialogues.speaker: TIM, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: That certainly isn't good news. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There it i 88C. 189

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (amazed at the stupidity of what Tim just said) "That certainly isn't good news?". What a genius.

dialogues.speaker: VAN SERTMA, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: No one is taking seriously the extent of the risks here.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: What do you think the world should be doing?

dialogues.speaker: VAN SERTMA, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: (to the camera; time for a commercial) Thank you. Now this.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (to Jenny) What do you think the world should be doing? Does everyone do what they didn't have time to do, or what they were afraid to do? What happens to everyone's morals?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Morals? Eric where are you going...

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: In social crisis, there's a collective unconscious yearning for the disaster everyone pretends to fear...

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Eric, why don't you just ask?

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Ask? What? What do you want me to ask?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: If the world is coming to an end, why not just have sex. S.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: No, no, no, Jenny, keep this in the abstract as much as you can. It's much sexier to be vague. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ERIC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The longer we talk about abstract morals, and the weirder the conversation gets, the longer and more twisted your sentences, the more I know what you'll be like in bed.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Well, that's quite a long and twisted sentence you've got there.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Maybe that should tell you something... They burst out laughing at the absurdity of this conversation. He kisses her. They look at each other and start laughing again.

dialogues.speaker: LEO AND SARAH'S NEIGHBORHOOD
dialogues.text: Leo rides his bike up the street fast, knapsack slung ove one shoulder, standing on the pedals. The neighborhood's transformed. Every driveway has sprouted a tricked-out SUV: brush guards, twin Jerry cans, CB whips. Yards have six foot chain link fences, now guarded not by neighborho mutts, but by gnarled Junkyard dogs. Chainsaws fell prize family trees, drop them into the street for firewood. Sandbags piled in front of doors. Inside open garages, weekend warriors build bulk storage where the Buick used to sit. Fill the shelves with cases of canned goods, fifty pound sacks of flour, drums of oil Propane storage tanks are the new yard ornaments of choic Leo rides his bike up the Hotchner driveway, to the garag where Chuck Hotchner is carrying a drill. Leo comes up beside him as they pass Chuck's dirt bike, standing just inside the garage.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Mr. Hotchner?

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK HOTCHNER
dialogues.text: Who did I think I was going to be when I bought that bike?

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Well, every kid on the block wants one now, and every Mom on the block hates you for it. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK HOTCHNER
dialogues.text: Thank you, Leo, that's the best news I've had in years. Give mea hand.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. They go around to the porch where Chuck takes his drill t a steel bar over the window. Sarah's mother, Vicky, nurse the baby on the porch. She has a little portable TV, with a small screen. This plays in the background. We may see it or hear it:

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Nationally, authorities report that record numbers of Americans are taking their own lives, with more than twelve hundred suicides in the past twenty-four hours alone... (riot footage) It was another day of rioting for building supplies throughout the East. In Florida, a mob attacked and killed a Miami rental yard operator who was charging five thousand dollars an hour for backhoe and tractor rentals. Marines had to intervene to stop the violence... A big Deere combine plowing through green corn. Leo grabs the heavy bars going up over the bay window. He's startled by a big BOOM! Coming from a few doors down

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK HOTCHNER
dialogues.text: Bob Smith's using dynamite to dig a shelter in his backyard. Down the block a huge dust mushroom cloud rises behind a ranch house. Guess this passes for normal now. Chuck drills the bar into place. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Farmers in the Midwest continue to harvest their crops prematurely, even though Department of Agriculture officials are now threatening to impound farmland found to have been harvested early... (a beat) In Arizona, the stand-off between Army Rangers and the Armageddon Doomsday Militiamen entered its fifth day...

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Uh... Mrs. Hotchner...

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Sarah's on the hill.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 190C
dialogues.text: Leo runs up to the pretty hilltop. He finds Sarah sitting under a tree, the city spread out below them; they see th burning FIRES, hear the SIRENS, and the GUNSHOTS.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Where were you today? Ive been looking everywhere for you. How come you weren't at school?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: My Father said I didn't have to go. He said there's no point. Leo digs two wedding bands out of his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: I have a point.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Those are wedding rings.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Yeah, I got em from Jeremy Landers dad, he needed a Coleman lantern. Look at them, don t you get it? I figured it out.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: If you marry me, I can get you into the Ark. You'll be safe. I went to FCDA! They said that if you and I got married, then you're my family, and I can take you.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What about my parents? They're not your family, I can't leave my parents.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: You don't have to. I'm the famous Leo Biederman and I haven't used my fame for anything, but I got them to bring your family too, because we're going to be married. She looks at him. He's so young.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You're a sophomore in high school. And you're asking me to marry you so I can hide in a cave for two years.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: So you can live. So we can both live. So we can have children.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: But we are children. Really, we're just children.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Marry me, Sarah, please, marry me. It's the only way you'll survive. She studies him. He's changed. She understands something.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You love me. You know it, now, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Yeah. I love you. She leans in, and kisses him. His lips first, then his cheeks, his eyes, his neck. He kisses her back, still unsure, a boy. And then she slowly begins to unbutton his shirt. If he thinks she's coming with him, we might see from the way she kisses him that for her, this could be goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: STREETS OF AMERICA
dialogues.text: We move into windows...

dialogues.speaker: TOWNS AND CITIES
dialogues.text: Americans rich and poor wait by their phones.

dialogues.speaker: NEW YORK CITY
dialogues.text: We hear a phone RING. Everyone in the apartment rushes.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Hello? Yes... Yes, this is he..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Families by the phone; all waiting.

dialogues.speaker: REMOTE FARM HOUSES
dialogues.text: Some phones RING. Some don t. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SUBURBS
dialogues.text: Other phones RING. Others don't.

dialogues.speaker: LEO'S STREET
dialogues.text: The street's deserted, inside every brightly lit window a family waits for their phone to ring. Leo stands on Sarah's lawn in the dark. Inside her living room bay window, he can see the Hotchners waiting. Their phone isn't ringing.

dialogues.speaker: MSNBC ANCHOR DESK 202
dialogues.text: Jenny at the anchor desk. The dress around the newsroom has become very informal. No more coffee cups and Evians, now it's beer and wine. And everyone, absolutely everyone smokes.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Confusion over Civil Defense food distribution erupted into riots again today in Denver, and a number of other cities across the country. Film of EMPTY PRISONS.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Prison guards in California walked away from their jobs, and released prisoners on their way out. It's feared this trend will spread nationally. Ira stands in the hallway, looking through Stuart's offic window. Stuart's inside in a suit and tie, packing up a few mementos, that's it. Worth stops beside Ira, a beat. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: WORTH
dialogues.text: He tell you where's he going?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Home...

dialogues.speaker: WORTH
dialogues.text: Where's that?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: He didn't say... In the studio, Jenny continues. Film of RIOTING on screen

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: On the other side of the country, rioting continued for the second day at the Lorton Reformatory outside Washington, D.C. Prisoners there had heard of the inmate releases in California, and wanted to be set free as well.

dialogues.speaker: THE COMETS 204
dialogues.text: Continue their journey towards Earth. They're getting closer and closer. The sunlight striking them, warming the ice. The long comet trails lengthening.

dialogues.speaker: MESSIAH COCKPIT 205
dialogues.text: Tanner watches this on the computer monitor. Something catches his eye. He's not sure, makes some notes, a small sketch. Floats back into the crew quarters. It's a mess, hanging wires, blackened debris, broken equipment. The lights are low. Baker, Simon and Tulchinsky asleep. Tanner grabs a foil pack, sits across from Monash. Tanner squeezes the foil pack into his mouth. He wipes Monash's lips. This is tender. They talk quietly, not to waken anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: None of you children brought any real books to read, did you know that? I brought Moby Dick and Huckleberry Finn, and Baker and Simon had never read them. I'm afraid to ask you. Have you ever read Melville or Twain?

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: I'm a child of the movies, Fish. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: You got a shitty deal, Oren.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: Don't worry about me. Really... don't worry about me. (reaches to Tanner and brings him closer, so no one can hear) Y'know, all my life... you know what it's like for guys like us, you and me, we're the same... be the best... be the best. I gotta wife. I'ma father. I see little flashes of light, and color, I go to sleep and dream, but there's a part of me which is always awake now, so I... I get to see myself dreaming. I'm seeing things differently. (pause) How come they call you Fish?

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Spurgeon, Sturgeon, Fish. That took about fifteen minutes of my first day at Annapolis.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: Your boys went there?

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Yeah. Good men. Both of them. I don't see them as much as I used to when Mary was alive, she was always better at keeping the family together. Monash senses Tanner's unhappiness.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: You don't have to talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: You're married, you know what it's like. Every marriage has its good years and bad...we ended on a great one. Anyway... Let's get started. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: On what? Tanner pulls out a copy of Moby Dick. We can fade out on this.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: You have a child at home, a boy or girl, and that child needs a Daddy who knows about books, so here we go, Moby Dick, chapter one. "Call me Ishmael. Some years ago never mind how long precisely having little or no money in my purse, and nothing particular to interest me on the shore, I thought I would sail about a little and see the watery part of the world..."  100.

dialogues.speaker: 205B
dialogues.text: On Robin's TV: Jenny, then VIDEO FOOTAGE OF LOOTERS.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: In Columbus, Ohio looters continue to set fire to abandoned stores. The fires have been left to burn since many firefighters are no longer reporting for work. CLOSET: Beautiful dresses. Robin's hand in frame takes out one dress, then another, then puts them back and take out a beautiful antique robe. ON A MAKE-UP TABLE: Make-up, lipstick, perfume. Robin's hand picks up the lipstick.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Throughout Latin America's major cities, business districts have been abandoned to looting gangs. Military patrols have not succeeded in stopping the violence, and food and medical shortages in outlying areas have become critical. Emergency airlifts hate been ruled out as too dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A torch. People climbing a hill. More torches. Leo with his parents. Sarah with her family.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN'S TOWNHOUSE
dialogues.text: JEWELRY CASE: A collection of beautiful pieces, earrings, rings, necklaces, a locket. Robin holds up different earrings. She chooses something beautiful. She tries on rings, puts rings on a few fingers of each hand. She puts on a heart shaped locket.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: More street fighting in Moscow as food and fuel shortages continue. One observer at the U.S. Embassy describes the scene as pure anarchy. A group of Moscow officials chartered a helicopter to get out of the city, but when angry rioters heard about it they shot the chopper down. No one survived the crash. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LEO AND SARAH'S HILLTOP
dialogues.text: IN THE LIGHT: Leo and Sarah are brought to each other. A CLERGYMAN is there. Sarah is beautiful, flowers are in he hair. Leo is in a suit that's too small for him. The CLERGYMAN. His Bible.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: In Europe, rioting continues as the EEU general evacuation plan has fallen apart due to continuing disagreements among participants. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, because the national health services in many of these countries have stopped providing services, hospitals have become armed encampments to keep from being over-run by angry citizens. (a beat) Refugee camps, like this one near Syria, continue to form along national borders as nation after nation refuses passage to those seeking safer ground before the missile hits. The rings. Don has the ring. Parents are crying.

dialogues.speaker: CLERGYMAN
dialogues.text: to love.., cherish.., so help...

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The government in Mexico has outlawed the private use of gasoline and diesel fuel after a round of severe price-gouging. In Mexico City, residents are fleeing to higher ground on foot. Several thousand people were trampled when police tried to re-route the crowds from main streets leading out of the city.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN'S TOWNHOUSE CONTINUOUS
dialogues.text: The TV is turned off. LIVING ROOM: For the first time in the sequence, we see Robin in full frame. She puts on music. She lights the candles in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: CLERGYMAN
dialogues.text: till death do you part?

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN'S TOWNHOUSE CONTINUOUS
dialogues.text: The room is beautiful, she was right when she told Jenny that this was one of the most beautiful rooms in the worl (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She sits down and pours an old red wine into a large glas She is in a chair beside a photograph of Jenny and Jason, when Jenny was a child, on the beach.

dialogues.speaker: CLERYMAN
dialogues.text: Do you... Sarah...

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I do. Leo kisses Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN'S TOWNHOUSE
dialogues.text: Robin drinks her wine and closes her eyes. She is at peace.

dialogues.speaker: AN ARMY BUS
dialogues.text: Making it's way slowly down Leo's block, more fortress than transportation. Inside, the haunted, passing faces of the already chosen. On top, soldiers. The Biedermans and Hotchners are on the sidewalk, suitcases beside them. Other families stand sullenly on their lawns. The bus stops, soldiers pour out of the bus in full battl gear, form a perimeter. It's precise, frightening. A young LIEUTENANT with a clipboard jogs over.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: Biederman?

dialogues.speaker: DON BIEDERMAN
dialogues.text: That's us.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: IDs please. A small line; Ellen, Jane, Don, Leo and Sarah, the Hotchners. He checks IDs, shines his flashlight in their faces. Sends them to the bus. Don carries two suitcases.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Only one suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: DON BIEDERMAN
dialogues.text: It's our family photos, keepsakes.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: Only one suitcase is going, sir. I don't care which one. Don looks to his wife, stricken. Leo sets his bag down. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: I don't need my stuff, Dad. (shows his ID) This is my wife, Sarah. Here's our notarized marriage license. The Lieutenant takes it, reads. Nods toward the bus.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: ...okay. Get on. Leo and Sarah smile at each other. Start for the bus. The Lieutenant signals to his men.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's it, let's go. They close in behind Leo and Sarah. Leo turns, the Hotchner's have been left behind.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: The Hotchners are coming, too. The Lieutenant turns his small flashlight back on, studie the list. There's a long, torturous wait.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: h..n..e..r

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: Not here. He starts off again. Leo stops him again.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: They have to be there! FCDA [ficda] sent their names to the White House!

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: They aren't there.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Check again... please! The Lieutenant's getting annoyed, looks again. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: They're not on the list. (to his men)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go...!

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: They're here! They have to be! (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to the Hotchners) I put you on the list, they said you were on the list. Sarah, I put them on the list!

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK HOTCHNER
dialogues.text: (it hits him) We're not on the list.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: But... You said...

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK HOTCHNER
dialogues.text: We're not on the list...

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: But Sarah, and the baby...

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Sarah can come.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Tell them the baby is yours... Tell them the baby is yours.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: (to the Lieutenant ) This is our baby...

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: Oh, come on... I can't do that!

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: What do we do?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (help me, please...) Mommy... Daddy... I don't want to leave you... Don Biederman is behind Leo.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Leo, just grab her, get her inside! Leo and Don hold onto Sarah, she pulls back.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I can't!

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK HOTCHNER
dialogues.text: Sarah... Sarah... You have to go. He tries to push her onto the bus. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: Come or stay, girl... this bus is moving out!

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: I'm not going without you!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I can't leave my family!

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Sarah! Get on the bus.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I don't want to leave you!

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK HOTCHNER
dialogues.text: You don't know what you're doing, Sarah...

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Listen to them! You'll die if you stay here, you know that! (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (resolute) If I die, I'll live on in you, in your memory. Tears run down Leo's face. She leans in, kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you love me. You'll go... The bus STARTS. She stares into his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please... Leo backs slowly away from Sarah, anguished. She nods, encouraging him to keep walking. He's to the bus door Don pushes him up on board. The Lieutenant climbs on. The bus doors close. It PULLS AWAY. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Leo rushes to the back window, stares out at Sarah, his hand smashed against the glass, as if to touch her. She waves, her mother sobs in her father's arms. And Leo's gone.

dialogues.speaker: MSNBC STUDIOS
dialogues.text: Jenny's Assistant takes us through the now sparsely populated MSNBC. Only a few desks are occupied, most have gone to be with their families. She KNOCKS on Stuart's old office door, now Worth's. He hasn't done anything to personalize it. Jenny has her feet up, Eric's there, Ira. They're watching footage of the interior of the Ark ona monitor.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Jenny...

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Here I am.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: It's for you. It's the coroner's office. Everyone is quiet now. Jenny takes the phone.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (apprehensive) This is Jenny Lerner. (listens) Yes. Yes. Robin Lerner. Yes. My mother. Sixty-one. Yes... That was her address, yes... What time? Everyone is watching her. She's crying while she talks.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll be right there. Thank you. Thank you very much. Thank you. She hangs up the phone. Everyone in the room knows that something awful just happened. Jenny walks out.  104.

dialogues.speaker: 217D
dialogues.text: Jenny and a CLERK at a counter where she collects Robin's things, the rings, necklace, and earrings she put on befo she died. Everything fits in a manila envelope.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Sign here. And sign here.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: That's it?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: You'll need to make arrangements. The funeral homes haven't been very responsive in the last few weeks. Everyone's waiting to see what happens. Jenny can't talk. She goes outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the rain. Cabs pass by. There's one that's free. It stops for her. She's about to get in when her father pull up in his car and opens his window.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Jenny! Come with me. Jenny whips open his passenger door.

dialogues.speaker: JASON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come with me.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: You're too late, I already took care of it.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Jenny, get in the car. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: JASON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It wasn't my fault.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I don't give a shit, go tell Chloe.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: She left to be with her parents, they're scared. She'll come back, I hope.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: You deserve it. You deserve to be alone! He gets out of his car.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: No, no, I don't. Get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Don't you dare get out of that car. Jason reaches to her, but she pulls her hand away and the bag she is holding opens up, spilling jewelry. Jason gets out of the car, he chases the locket, but Jenny grabs it.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't touch it! It's mine. Now he's soaking in the rain, too.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Well. So. I'm sorry for you.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I feel like an orphan. She gets in the cab and leaves Jason in the rain. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LEO'S BUS
dialogues.text: 220 Leo and his family are on the crowded bus. Leo stares out the window, lost, empty. Outside, soldiers try to hold ba a mob jamming the entrance the bus can force it's way through a set of heavily armed gates between tall fences topped with razor wire. The whole area's lit up like Mond Night Football.

dialogues.speaker: SECTION LEADER
dialogues.text: Welcome to the Ark. I'm the section leader for Orange 254. Remember that, that's what we're going to be calling home for the next two years. Please gather your things and follow me to the orientation gallery. They file off the bus. Leo steps down into the --

dialogues.speaker: LIMESTONE CLIFF STAGING AREA
dialogues.text: People everywhere, heavily armed soldiers, trucks, GUNSHOTS, CHOPPERS coming and going. Animals are unloaded from railroad box cars not just cattle and sheep; lamas, pandas, tigers, peacocks, ostriches. Noah's Ark. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Huge piles of palleted grain are moved by forklifts, larg wooden crates move past marked "National Gallery" and "Library of Congress". A PA system BOOMS:

dialogues.speaker: PA SYSTEM, (VO)
dialogues.text: Please proceed in an orderly fashion to the orientation gallery for medical examination and inoculation. Please proceed in an orderly fashion... They do as they're told, frightened, confused. No more in control of what's happening to them than the cattle being herded beside them.

dialogues.speaker: SECTION LEADER
dialogues.text: There are a million people living here. Two hundred food service centers. You'll be eating freeze dried beans and vegetables, and fish sticks, a lot of fish sticks... Ahead, massive doors open into the cliffs. The dark tunnel's uninviting, ominous. Leo stops. His father realizes.

dialogues.speaker: DON BIEDERMAN
dialogues.text: Leo...?

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: I'm not coming. A beat. Jane and Ellen turn back.

dialogues.speaker: LEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have to go back for Sarah. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Leo, come with us right now.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: I'm going back for her, we're going to make it.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: We're fifteen hundred miles from home.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: It's beyond everyone's control.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: She's my wife.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: Please don't go.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: I'll see you again. I'll see all of you again. Don pulls out money, and he pulls off his watch and his ring.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Don't let him go.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: He'll need something for trade. And take this... He gives Leo his Swiss Army knife.

dialogues.speaker: DON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry your childhood was stolen from you like this. Leo hugs them all and begins to back up.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Mom, Janie... I love you... His little sister waves softly. Leo turns away, walks fast, not daring to look back. Disappears into the crowd.  221

dialogues.speaker: RICHMOND
dialogues.text: FROM A HELICOPTER we fly into the city center, past abandoned cars and looted stores, there's trash everywher on the streets, stacked in vacant lots, find CIVIL DEFENS WORKERS shepherding a crowd into an underground parking garage.

dialogues.speaker: WOLF BIEDERMAN IMPACT
dialogues.text: They remind you of nothing so much as refugees; pushing shopping carts overflowing with their belongings, walking beside their overloaded cars pioneers heading west. And finally, WE FIND Sarah, carrying her baby sister. Vicky drives their stuffed to the ceiling Astro Minivan, her father pulls a cart loaded with mattresses. They follow the crowd down into the parking garage, past distribution area manned by CD volunteers handing out blankets, crates of freeze dried food, Ensure. Vicky pulls the van into the first vacant spot. Other families are already setting up camp.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: ...Home sweet home... I'll start unloading the van. Hands the baby to her mother. Vicky looks to Chuck bleakl

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Oh god... Chuck wraps an arm around her, hugs her. 221

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny is on the newsroom floor, talking to Worth.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: They're working completely by press release now. I don't feel like a reporter anymore.

dialogues.speaker: WORTH
dialogues.text: What about Entrekin? Ira is coming over.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: He hasn't taken my call in two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Jenny.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: IRA
dialogues.text: Your Father is here. And there's Jason.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Excuse me. And she goes to him.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello, Jason.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I can't stay long, I'm leaving the city, but I wanted to show you something. I wanted to show you that you're not an orphan. I have proof that you're not an orphan. Look. He takes a few photographs out of his Jacket pocket. Thes are pictures of Jason and Jenny when Jenny was a baby. Th are pictures of Jenny and Jason on the beach, at a beach house. These are not snapshots, they're black and white, beautifully exposed and printed; a great camera, a good photographer.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Where's Mom?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Behind the camera. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: She took these pictures?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Yes. She was an artist. You don't remember when they were taken?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I'm five years old here. How would I remember that?

dialogues.text: Chuck and Vicky Hotchner lean against their stopped van. He has his arm around her. She lets him hold her. He looks up... Everyone is looking up, she looks up... there's the comet.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK HOTCHNER
dialogues.text: Biederman. People get out of their cars, slowly. WE BOOM UP, to see miles of jammed road, all traffic has stopped as a millio people make peace with the end of their lives. 276 277

dialogues.speaker: COUNTRY ROAD
dialogues.text: Leo and Sarah ROAR off the freeway, FLY past an endless line of cars crawling slowly into the green hills. Sarah sees the comet first.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Oh no... Streaking overhead. Leo yells over the NOISE of the bike.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Fifteen minutes after it hits we'll feel the shock wave! Hold on...! He LAYS on the gas, Sarah holding onto Leo and the baby for dear life.

dialogues.speaker: NEW YORK CITY
dialogues.text: Stuart walks calmly along the street in a suit and tie. People run past, cars JAMMED bumper to bumper in the stre HONKING, trying desperately to get out of the city. But Stuart's calm, relaxed. Finds a -- Curbside Starbucks coffee cart, umbrella, it's deserted. Makes himself a cup of espresso. The portable TV on the cart now only STATIC. Grabs a New York Times from an abandoned news stand. The NY tabloids hanging from it's sides scream "COMET TO CITY: DROP DEAD!" And "THE FAT LADY SINGS!", the Times simply states, "Wolf, Biederman Impact Imminent" and in smaller type, "Scientists Disagre On Extent Of Destruction". He walks through the chaos and out into Washington Square among the pigeons. Sits on the steps near the Arch, sets his coffee to one side, lights a cigarette, opens his pap

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The comet is coming to ground. Forest and fields on shore IGNITE, the ocean BOILS as the comet SPLASHES into the se a few miles off the coast. The white hot tip of the comet breaks the surface. The hole in the ocean begins to spread. Merges with the earth and FROM ABOVE, the circle of the impact spreads. On shore, the earth RIPPLES away in harmony with the water. And then the shock wave catches up with the fires, BLOWIN them out as it KNOCKS the forests flat. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Farms and towns are thrown into the air, then roads and c SHOCKED into vapor by the impact. The ocean wave begins t form, TOWERING above. WE'RE MOVING fast... Down the East Coast ... Faster than the speed of sound... Cities COLLAPSE, forests, bridges. Everything in its path.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA COUNTRYSIDE
dialogues.text: Jenny drives down the deserted country road, heading east when SUDDENLY the ground RIPPLES towards her, as if the highway were a rug and God was shaking out the dust. Tree FALL, telephone poles SNAP. The car FLIES over the sudden three foot speed bump. SLAMS back to the road, with a metal GRINDING THUMP, Jenny keeps going.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTRY ROAD
dialogues.text: Leo and Sarah. The RIPPLING earth catches up to them from behind, moving fast. Sarah sees, SCREAMS to Leo.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Oh God...! It catches them. The motorcycle JUMPS, bounces up over the rolling ground. They land HARD, Leo struggles to keep the bike upright, Sarah clutching the bundled Baby.

dialogues.speaker: OCEAN
dialogues.text: The wave is a thousand feet high and moves across the oce in a line that stretches past the horizon. OIL RIGS are simply swallowed whole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny arrives at the beach colony, with beautiful weather old ramshackle cottages behind fences on the dunes. She has the photographs that Jason gave her at MSNBC. She has found the cottage in the background. Ahead of her, through a break in the houses, a path to th sea. A dog barks. The birds wheel overhead. She walks to the sand. She takes off her shoes. She's carrying a bag and she flings it away. No more than a hundred or so people are on the beach, families, old people, children, and dogs. A little girl h a cockatiel in a birdcage. She lets it go. The bird flies away. There's a boy in a wheelchair. His parents set him on the sand, near the water's edge. Couples are kissing, families are hugging each other. A man alone plays frisbe with his black lab. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 290E CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Someone is playing the guitar. There's Jason, standing alone, looking out at the sea. He comes to her.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Jenny...

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: When I was eleven, I stole money from your wallet.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: When you were a baby, I dropped you on your head.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: When you came to the studio, and you showed me the pictures, I lied when I told you that I didn't remember. I was so mad at you, because I remembered everything. I remember the day, it was a perfect happy day. We were right over here... We were all alone on the beach, and Mom was really upset because she'd left her tripod in the house. I'm here because I wanted you to know. They walk to the water's edge.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Thank you. I miss her, too. Jenny stares at her Father.

dialogues.speaker: JASON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wish I could make up all that lost time for you.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (no irony, she means this) We have the rest of our lives. And then a terrible sound, not the wave, something else: The sky is filled with SQUAWKING sea birds flying inland, dense cloud of gulls, terns, and pelicans. Everyone on th beach begins to join hands in a line at the water's edge, gently, without the need to talk. The DOGS run away from them, away from the water. And then the sea before them is SUCKED away in a massive tide, exposing fish and an old wreck. Something foams on horizon. Here it comes. Imagine the Santa Monica mountain rolling toward you, faster than the speed of sound. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: 290E CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jenny grabs her father.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Daddeeee! Father holds daughter. The sound is DEAFENING. And they'r gone.

dialogues.speaker: 290G OMIT 290G
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FREEWAY
dialogues.text: The wave sweeps down the freeway, gathering thousands of cars in its foam. The Hotchners wait, holding each other. Vicky looks up at her husband, smiles. And they disappear as the tidal wave sucks up fifty thousand cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two F-16's SCREAM into view, towards the Manhattan skylin They close in on the STATUE OF LIBERTY. They veer off in opposite directions as the GIANT WAVE enters frame and th sky starts to darken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wave sweeps over lower Manhattan, around and between and over the twin towers of the World Trade Center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It tears through Soho.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Times Square, you can see it coming up Broadway and Seventh Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON SQUARE
dialogues.text: The rushing crowds around Stuart, stop. Climb out of thei cars, look eastward. A tremendous NOISE. Stuart looks up from his paper. Takes a final deep drag of his cigarette, and he's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking up at the Chrysler building we see an ocean liner tossed by the wave into the skyscraper's top floors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM ABOVE: looking down at the Empire State Building as the wave surges through mid-town.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: FROM BELOW: As the Statue of Liberty floats face down abo the drowned city. 291 291 292

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 293 294 FROM THE SURFACE OF THE WATER: the wave has passed, leavi one tower of the World Trade Center leaning against the other, water draining from the shattered windows.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA HILLS
dialogues.text: Leo and Sarah ROAR over a hill to see a mountain road ris above, traffic JAMMED all the way up. Sedans have tried t negotiate the shoulder and gotten stuck. There's nowhere go. Leo idles for a moment. Looks around desperately, Steve McQueen in The Great Escape. Behind them, in the fa distance, something is COMING. He REVS the engine.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Hold on! FLIES off into the brush, looking for a trail, anything. The bushes and branches SLAP at their faces, SCRATCH and TEAR. A deer trail. Not much but they'll take it. It's steep, not meant for motorcycles. The wrong move and they'll FLY off into the woods. Dirt SAILS off the tires as they SKID and SLAM over branches and decomposing leaves. They come around a bend, a huge TREE down ahead. Leo brak to try to stop, but the bike SKIDS underneath them. They down. Leo and Sarah falling, SLIDING behind it. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The cycle SMASHES into the tree, SLAMS up and over it ina twisting somersault of metal and paint. And suddenly, it's silent. Leo sits up, clothes torn, covered in mud and dirt. Crawls back to Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: LEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sarah...? Sarah...?! She's a few feet behind him, face scrapped, more concerne about the baby still strapped to her chest.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I think he's okay... CRYING like hell, but alright. Leo pulls her up.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: We have to keep going, can you run? She nods. He drags her behind him over the tree, the bike a mangled mess, the back wheel still spinning.

dialogues.speaker: THE WAVE
dialogues.text: It covers the countryside, the crest of the beast eating everything in its way, devouring entire states.

dialogues.speaker: FOREST
dialogues.text: Leo and Sarah running. People behind them, above them.

dialogues.speaker: THE WAVE
dialogues.text: It reaches the base of the hills. An immense force, the water piling up on the mountain as easily as water ina bathtub surges over the side if you give it a push.

dialogues.speaker: EXT SPACE 298
dialogues.text: The United States coastline has changed. Cape Cod is gone New York City and Long Island. No Chesapeake Bay. No Carolinas or Florida. The ocean reaches inland from the White Mountains of New Hampshire to the Poconos, to the B Ridge Mountains and the Appalachians.

dialogues.speaker: INT MESSIAH 298A
dialogues.text: The bombs are strapped to the cabin table, their LEDs blinking 0:00:20. Ready to be started.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: We're at perigee. Wolf contact in three minutes, forty-five seconds. Wolf dead ahead, heading for earth. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: We'll never be closer to home then we are right now. They watch the earth below them.

dialogues.speaker: HEFTER, (ON COM)
dialogues.text: Messiah, we've got some people down here who want to talk to you...

dialogues.speaker: MOUNTAIN ROAD
dialogues.text: Leo and Sarah CRASH out of the woods onto the road, out o breath. HEAR the thing behind them. Look back -- White foam, DEAFENING noise, planes overhead. People run out of the forest, the water rising behind them, ROARING up out of the woods. The Atlantic Ocean now two hundred miles west of where it was this morning.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON SPACE CENTER
dialogues.text: The families of the astronauts, monitors set up in front of them, Simon's scratchy image. His fiancee, Wendy, crying.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON, (ON MONITOR)
dialogues.text: Wendy, if you let this ruin your life, I'm going to come back to haunt you.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Please, come back and haunt me.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE MESSIAH 301
dialogues.text: It's Baker's turn, her husband and two daughters.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Take care of Daddy for me, okay? (the little girls nod) David, you know what I want to say.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID BAKER, (ON MONITOR)
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON SPACE CENTER
dialogues.text: Next up is Tulchinsky. He starts in English, switches to Russian and then a SIMULTANEOUS TRANSLATOR takes over.

dialogues.speaker: TULCHINSKY, (ON MONITOR)
dialogues.text: I was in love with three women in my life. You know who you are. (in Russian, translated) I was stupid, I couldn't decide. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: TULCHINSKY, (ON MONITOR)
dialogues.text: Each of you is beautiful and unique and I didn't want to give that up. But I loved you, don't ever doubt that, I loved you all...

dialogues.speaker: MOUNTAIN ROAD
dialogues.text: Leo and Sarah are trying to make it to higher ground but the wave CRESTS over the road. CATCHES them.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Sarah!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Leo! LIFTS them up as they're carried by the water, TURNED and TOSSED, ROLLED and BUMPED together.

dialogues.speaker: THE MESSIAH 304
dialogues.text: Wolf looms very large, dead ahead. Tulchinsky helps Monas get in place for the camera. Baker's counting down.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Wolf contact in two minutes, thirty seconds. Hefter's face appears in the Houston monitor, distressed.

dialogues.speaker: HEFTER, (ON MONITOR)
dialogues.text: Oren, Mariette was up at your folks place in Utah, we sent a plane for her, but she isn't here yet. The other's watch Monash's face. The clock's down to 2:14

dialogues.speaker: HEFTER
dialogues.text: And Fish, your sons are both on active duty, we couldn't get them back here in time. I'm sorry. We tried. Spurgeon, I was wrong. You were the best man for the job. Tanner nods, not surprised.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Mitch? I want to say good-bye to Mary. I want to tell her I love her, and that, ever since we've been apart, every day, I think about her. (then) I'm coming home, Mary. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Coming up on target 126 miles, RDOT .3, 1 degree X, 15 degrees Yous Tanner looks away from the monitor, takes the controls.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: 115 miles, .3, 2 degrees X, 13 Yous

dialogues.speaker: SPACE 305
dialogues.text: Wolf rolls slowly, the vent clearly ahead of them. The Messiah heads into the mass of coma and rocks.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON SPACE CENTER
dialogues.text: Mariette, with the baby, runs into the building, military escorts struggling to keep up.

dialogues.speaker: MARIETTE
dialogues.text: Wait...oh god...wait...!

dialogues.speaker: WOLF 307
dialogues.text: The comet is nearing the earth's atmosphere.

dialogues.speaker: THE MESSIAH 308
dialogues.text: They're BANGING around, the worst, downhill four-wheel drive off road experience you can imagine. Tanner tries to hold it on target.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: 76 miles. Wolf impact in forty- five seconds...

dialogues.speaker: MARIETTE, (ON MONITOR)
dialogues.text: Oren?... Oren, are you there?! Monash turns to his wife's voice. Her picture breaking up as they FIGHT their way through the dense coma.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: Mariette? I'm here, I can hear you.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON SPACE CENTER
dialogues.text: The terrifyingly jumpy interior of the ship and Monash on the static filled monitor. Mariette holds up their child.

dialogues.speaker: MARIETTE
dialogues.text: Baby... This is your father. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: Mariette!

dialogues.speaker: MARIETTE
dialogues.text: His name is Oren, I named him after you. OREN JR. Dadda!

dialogues.speaker: HONASH
dialogues.text: Oren. Oren Jr. holds up to the camera a rocket toy he has been clutching. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: THE MESSIAH 310
dialogues.text: We see the image of the baby and the rocket on the Messia monitor.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: What happened? OREN JR. Look!

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: (helping out Monash) He's holding up a little rocket.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: Oh, what a powerful rocket you have. The Baby coos and giggles.

dialogues.speaker: SIMON
dialogues.text: He's laughing.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: I can hear him. Mariette...

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: In 40 miles...25 seconds... She keeps counting. Tanner yells back to Tulchinsky.

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: Prepare to synchronize the nukes.

dialogues.speaker: MONASH
dialogues.text: ...I'm hugging you both right now... I'm holding you...

dialogues.speaker: MARIETTE
dialogues.text: We're holding you! Tulchinsky has a makeshift button, wires run from it to the nukes. 0:00:20 frozen on their LEDs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tulchinsky hits the button and the nukes begin to count down in perfect unison...19...18...

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's been a pleasure serving with you, Commander. Tanner doesn't take his eyes off the vent. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: TANNER
dialogues.text: The honor's all mine, Andy...

dialogues.speaker: MARIETTE
dialogues.text: We love you, Oren...

dialogues.speaker: JOHNSON SPACE CENTER
dialogues.text: Mariette's crying, hell, everybody's crying. Monash's face, his hand touching the camera. And then, he's gone. The monitor suddenly filled with STATIC. The baby leans forward trying to touch the screen, mystified.

dialogues.speaker: THE COMET AND THE MESSIAH 312
dialogues.text: Wolf begins heating up as the Messiah ROARS into the vent swallowed whole: Nothing. Didn't it work? And then, a BLINDING light SHOOT out... and BOOM. Everything goes WHITE.

dialogues.speaker: THE HILLSIDE 313
dialogues.text: Leo and Sarah sit up in the middle of the flooded road. The water draining away as the wave recedes. Sarah still has the CRYING baby in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: ...look... THE SKY: overhead, far away, Wolf and a brilliant light followed by a massive rolling wave of THUNDER that shakes the earth. They walk to the edge of the road, look out over the valley, the ocean slowly receding below.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: It's going away. And then all the pieces from the explosion begin HITTING the atmosphere. The greatest meteor shower in history, FIREWORKS in the day brighter than at night. The entire sky filled with color and light, STREAKING, BURNING. Leo can't speak. Sarah holds Leo, the baby. The baby stares at the sky, the ocean, mesmerized. Begins to LAUGH...
